review_title: Wells Fargo is losing many good people
pros: Some really good managers and colleagues.  Better than average benefits.
cons: Many really good people are leaving Wells Fargo.  In the district in which I worked, in less than one year, three District Managers left; at my former store, the Store Manager, every Teller except one and my Personal Banker colleague left the company.  It's well known that Wells Fargo is involved in numerous lawsuits filed by current and former employees; these lawsuits deal (broadly) with an overly aggressive sales culture that allegedly had led to questionable sales behaviors.  In addition, the SEC reportedly is in the process of conducting several probes into Wells Fargo.  In January, Wells Fargo, undoubtedly, because of the negative attention it has been receiving because of the lawsuits and SEC probes, "rolled out" a new culture.  Previously, Wells Fargo management frequently throughout the day aggressively pushed Team Members to "sell, sell, sell" and told Team Members how many sales they needed to close the sales gaps for themselves and their stores and what potentially would happen if the sales numbers were not met and sales gaps not closed.  Now, managers are not supposed to demonstrate this behavior daily; instead, they are to meet with Team Members once weekly to "review sales goals and sales gaps."  The new culture rolled out:  It's all about the customer experience, do right by the customer.  All well and good however, sales goals virtually have remained the same as before.  What managers had expressed verbally throughout the day i.e. "sell, sell, sell" now is done by requiring Personal Bankers to fill out workbooks daily, indicating how they are going to improve the customer experience, all of the tasks they need to complete and how they are going to achieve their sales goals.  Managers now review the workbooks at the start of the business day and at the end of the business day. End of business day workbook reviews always conclude by the manager asking how the Team Members will improve their performance the next business day.  The aggressive sales culture remains, only now it is "kinder and gentler."  People are moving on from Wells Fargo, in search of environments in which they are able to do their jobs, do the right things and not have to endure a truly aggressive sales culture that has led to questionable behaviors to achieve sales.

review_title: Marketing is a beaurocratic assembly line
pros:
Once you get to middle management, the salary and bonus structures are good.
Benefits are outstanding, but decreasing and inflexible
Remote working options can sometimes be arranged, depending on role and manager
cons:
Marketing has been removed from the lines of business and centralized under one umbrella.  Senior management has imposed the same structure for national brand campaigns as single page flyers.  No exaggeration:  a net new marketing asset (whether an email or an integrated campaign) will take 9 MONTHS.  It will take  4-6 weeks just to get the Strategic Assessment Brief written (and rewritten 3 more times) before it is approved by 2 layers of management.  Then, once in the queue, it can still be deprioritized if other projects are deemed more impactful.   
No one is in charge of a project from end-to-end.  Strategy hands off to Integrated Marketing who hands off to Marketing Execution and the In-House Agency.  And often our Insights & Analytics team (who is woefully under-staffed) will be tapped to provide data and forecasting.  When you include multiple rounds of ultra-conservative Compliance review, you can see why even the most basic project can take the better part of a year to produce.

pros:
Monday thru Friday day shift schedule, good location, nice cafeteria.










































On the plus side, it's Monday thru Friday, a regular schedule, a full if pricey cafeteria, lovely grounds to walk around on your lunch break, and fairly good security. Some teams are much better than others.
cons:
Wells Fargo at this call center only hires new CSRs through employment agencies, so if you accept this position be prepared to make $13.50 to $14.00 an hour for the same work that your "official" Wells Fargo employed team members are making $19 to $25 an hour to do. If anything, you will work harder, because all the calls not requiring "special handling" will get routed to you. You will take back to back calls all day every day, while your team members chat about their lives and weekend plans. And I know, "I get paid either way", but sure not paid enough.
We are promised a good chance of being "hired on" after a certain amount of time and proving ourselves as valuable employees, and finally attaining the job security, pay increase, PTO, vacation days, sick time, and stock options, but believe me, it's just a carrot on a stick held in front of you to make you give maximum effort for minimum compensation.
Why are they paying agencies big money to bring us in, full background checks, FBI fingerprinting, eight weeks of paid training, and then hiring only one agency person on in the past 6 months? Because there is a possibility this site may shut down in the next year or two, and all agency employees aren't going to need that severance package, right?
And good attendance, people skills, and work ethic won't get you hired as an official employee, you have to market Wells Fargo products. "It's not selling stuff, it's 'having a conversation' ". OK. After the Wells Fargo scandals over marketing products, (Google it if you don't know, I had to) you would not think you'd have to sell stuff to people who call in with concerns about keeping their homes to get hired here, but you do. If someone calls in looking to refinance, sure, but if someone calls in and immediately launches in to "why weren't my taxes paid out of my escrow?!?!", and there's a note on their account to try to sell them another mortgage, it is held against you if you don't do it! The survey system is ridiculous, their opinion of your service is lumped right in with how the customer perceives Well Fargo. The American people don't trust or respect Wells Fargo, and you are not paid enough to try to make the overpaid bosses look good. As an agency employee, you will be treated differently, all my fellow agency employees will back me up on this. Left out of team potlucks, generally left to our own devices to figure stuff out, reminded snidely to "call Robert Half, or Dysis, or Sparks" or whoever your employment agency is, if a customer recommends in a review that you get a raise or a compliment. If you think your agency pay is in anyway compensation for what you'll be doing, think again. If you think you're so awesome you'll be hired on within a year, think again.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a good company wanting to be great, but not yet living up to it's potential
pros: Because WF is a financial services company, not just a bank, there are many diverse jobs availabe and WF encouranges hiring from within.   Career advancement is supported and employees are encouraged to take advantage of educational opportunities, both internal and external.   The company holds to the highest ethical standards, which made me proud to work there; regulatory restrictions often made providing great customer service a challange, but there was an honest commitment to doing so.  WF has great potential as a company and has largely avoided the excesses of the sub-prime lending debacle.
cons: WF is actually a conglomerate of companies.  While an effort was (and is) being made to create "One Wells Fargo", this has not been fully realized.  Customers assume WF is one entity, but internally responsibilities are divided, and sometimes shared, between various divisions.  This creates frustration for customers with issues and inefficiencies in problem resolution.   The retail sales environment hinders the development and retention of experienced bankers by continuously raising sales requirements and creating gimmicky bonus programs that make it difficult for bankers to meet all the requirements to earn their bonuses.  Burnout is a real problem in non-retail depertments as well.

job_title: Treasury Services Associate III in Melville, NY
pros: Solid company with a long standing history.
cons: Advancing your career is challenging as you are one of many and need to really be in front and on top of your managers to get seen and recognized. Compensation is also very low and merit increases do not even cover cost of living increases. A very conservative company.

job_title: Phone Banker I in Roanoke, VA
pros: Great Benefits and pay. Community involvement is huge with this company.  Food in Cafeteria is always good and fresh.  This company has a diverse culture which is awesome.  There is various departments to work for.  Management is great because they really care about you and often ask for feedback on how to better their processes.
cons: Parking is too far from building in their operations location.  At times there is unrealistic expectations as it relates to sales and processes of loans.

job_title: Phone Banker I in Homewood, AL
pros: The benefits are great and the ability to advance, or at least receive a pay raise, are plentiful. Short Term Disability insurance, tuition reimbursement, even daycare assistance are standard benefits to the job.
cons: It's incredibly tedious, stressful, and demanding. The sales goals are ever increasing with the regulations steadily making these goals harder to obtain. Burn out comes quick. Unless you have plans on becoming a supervisor or using this as a way to make a lateral move to another part of the company, consider it a brief stepping stone.

review_title: It's a job, not a career.
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Phoenix, AZ
pros: You get bonuses ranging from 200-600 based on your number of sales. If the location does well with their customer service overall, each team member receives anywhere from 200-600 as well. These bonuses are quarterly every 3 months.
cons: Very stressful and pushy environment to exceed sales quota. At the end of the day, it doesn't matter how well you've done good at something, or how long you've been there. They typically won't have your back. You can only move up higher in the company if you play along with their politics.

review_title: What to expect at Wells Fargo
job_title: Business Banking Specialist in Spring, TX
pros: A lot of opportunity to grow. 401k options are good. Array of products especially in business lending, are great.
cons: In retail, relationship banking is not a priority, selling "widgets" are. Store mgrs are given a lot of autonomy, so they can be your best friend or worst enemy. So far two mgrs I have worked with, leave a lot to be desired. Health benefits just took a big turn for the worst in 2014.

job_title: Business Liaison Manager in Addison, TX
pros: Great benefits, opportunities to advance your career within and outside of multiple lines of business. Great exposure to different management styles and goals.
cons: The company is large, so change is slow. Outdated technology (laptops) with limited RAM. Information is maintained within silos and rarely is shared to benefit other business lines.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Riverside, CA
pros: Employee benefits. College reimbursement. Banking hours were amazing too. Off Sunday.
cons: Management. Company morals. Hourly pay for amount of work they expect.

pros: There was really some good people working in my location. But because of the sales goals they didn't stay with the company.
cons: Daily goals for checking accounts and its not about good quality clients. All about the numbers. Daily conference calls asking about how many account you have on the board.

review_title: Good Place to Start, Bad Place to Stay
pros:
Good place to start
Wells Fargo encourages you to get your licenses and will pay for all study material and exams
cons:
Low pay
Not much career growth opportunity
High turnover
Wells Fargo cares more about being a bank than a brokerage

pros: Stable career. It is hard to get fired for underperforming. If you are interested in a sales career, there are a lot of opportunities here.
cons: Very sales oriented. Management does not care about anything but numbers. You can be over performing, exceeding sales goals, and have outstanding customer service, yet you will never hear a "Thank you" from upper management, only "why didn't you do x, y and z?"

review_title: If I could give zero stars I would
job_title: Phone Banker I in El Monte, CA
pros: Absolutely nothing! Horrible place to work! Will not recommend it to my worst enemy!
cons: It's all about pushing sales! They do not care wether it benefits the customer! Extremely micromanage, handle time, there is no nice way to say no... I only lasted there 6 months, and I don't know how I lasted that long in such a horrible place

pros: Wells Fargo has built up a very good company culture. I was in an IT support role where the work life balance was excellent and my team was supportive. There are a ton of opportunities for lateral movement.
cons: As with any company, the team can make or break the experience. For those trying to go into credit analysis, expect long hours and a ton of stress.

job_title: Research and Remediation Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good training, and offer lunch/ breakfast at least two of the five working days each week. Working time frame quite flexible, you can come at 6:00am and leave at 2:30pm as far as u talk to ur manager first.
cons: Daily work quite the same, a lot of people lost their passion after working for several months. There is mandatory ot each week and a lot of people quit. Hard to find balance between work and life

pros: The usual - OK benefits, predictable policies, a lot of departments and divisions to get into (if you can) with a wide range of opportunities, skills, and constraints. A good place to start a career.
cons: Big companies are a haven for narcissistic managers, HR has too much power (results in tolerance of non-performers), VERY difficult to cross organizational lines into new positions even with education and training, risk-obsessed, mediocre compensation outside of sales. Poor work/life balance in supervisory jobs. Continued outsourcing of employee-facing functions making for waste and dissatisfaction. Not good for mid-career folks.

job_title: Store Manager in Port Townsend, WA
pros: good pay, great benefits, upward and lateral movement availability
cons: gaming, gaming, gaming...some areas of the US are worse than others. In Michigan it started from the top and worked it's way down to the tellers but Michigan WF management was nothing like I was taught from Corporate Wells Fargo in Washington State

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in San Jose, CA
pros:
- very professional work place environment
- lots of opportunities for growth, even into different fields/specialties
- fair pay
- customer service is prioritized (only maybe behind sales)
cons:
- atmosphere depends largely on management
- tremendous sales pressure
- work is will most likely keep you very busy most of the day
- sometimes product knowledge training is inadequate to prepare you

pros:
Nice coworkers that face the same daily pain and suffering that you do.
Crockpots galore 
Decide hours. Who doesn't love having Sundays off?
cons:
Ridiculously high goals to reach.

They write you up a ton if you are not hitting those goals.

They have a threshold that you can meet and management try to push you past that because they don't get a bonus if everyone doesn't hit their goals. They are very rude about this.

Management very verbally abusive. I watched a manager belittle a banker till she was hyperventilating and crying. They had to call 911 to help her.

Very short staffed.

Too busy worrying about goals to make sure you're actually making the customer happy.

Sensitive documents left out with SSN that the cleaning crew could easily access.

pros: Great starting salary. Plenty of advancement opportunities. After becoming a banker you can move to any part of the company from there.
cons: There has been changes that are slowly taking place. Some changes are to prevent unethical behavior. Some are unnecessary. The recently changed the incentive structure. No one likes this change because there's less money available for incentive and you get a smaller bonus for the same production.

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist III in West Des Moines, IA
pros: They treat employees well. Regular fun days or food days. Great manager. Low stress environment. Almost never worried about work after I walked out the door each day.
cons: Manager was a great dude but had way too much on his plate to help with individual employees'  professional growth. Little opportunity for  advancement or to move within company. My actual work was very repetitive and mundane.

pros: Lot's of opportunity to have a much better pay grade within two years. They offer great benefits for health and university. The atmosphere is positive and inclusive.
cons: You really have to give up a lot of your personal life to succeed here. As you progress in your career, it becomes more and more about kissing up to customers and to your higher-ups. It's kind of disgusting.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Los Gatos, CA
pros: I got promoted twice (and got a raise) in a year. There are alot of positions to move up, so it's pretty easy to move up.
cons: The pay is awful. Very competitive sales goals. And the compensation received for the amount of work put in isn't very good. But my experiences/managers were pleasant and not too unreasonable so it was quite bearable.

review_title: Financial Advisor at Wells Fargo Advisors
job_title: Financial Advisor in Century City, CA
pros: Great initial training program and had lots of freedom with very little micro management.
cons: Very difficult commission quotas to meet for a newbie that doesn't have lots of connections to begin with.  All the advisors in my office were experienced and well established.  Every newcomer was eventually let go due to not reaching the very high commission quotas.  No ongoing training and no support after you go through the training program.

job_title: Personal Banker II in Atlanta, GA
pros: Opportunities are there for promotions and additional training if you're a hard worker and decent at your job. Fair pay compared to other banks. Great benefits with 401(K) match, tuition reimbursement, health insurance, time off, etc
cons: Quality of job depends HEAVILY on your management team and if you have a "bad" manager it can take a long time for anything to be done about it. Recently there have been lots of changes and the communications have not been very clear.

pros: The company seems to have a lot of potential to move around and advancing your career path. Work less than a year and see that the company tries their best to appreciate their employees. Got a promotion after working here less than a year. They values employees performance. Work hard and you will get what you want.
cons: It's a big company. Different departments will have different standards. Sometimes you can be curious how some employees have so much freetime to chat with coworkers and others don't.

pros: Wells Fargo overall is a good company to work for.
cons: There is a lot of manager discretion.

pros:
Recognition of employees.
Hardwork is genuinely rewarded.
Friendly team members.
Management was very co-operating.
Lots of free time when I joined.
Most of the weekends, we had team lunch or dinner and all kinds of entertainment.
15 days of annual leave and 15 days of casual leave plus holidays given by the company during festival time.
Positive approach towards work atmosphere.
On the whole twas a nice company to start with.
cons:
No extra pay for overtime.
If you do not end up in good manager's team, its difficult to get promoted.
The pay scale is comparatively low for beginners compared to other IT firms.

job_title: Full Time Teller in Los Angeles, CA
pros: There was paid two weeks training where we gained all the necessary information to become a teller or position beyond.
cons: I was promised I would be moved up to banker within a few months but I never got the promotion. Also Lunch breaks were very short.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Pinellas Park, FL
pros: Great PTO package, bonuses based on customer surveys, easy and consistent job
cons: Movement is slow, not much support if you want to develop outside of the Retail Bank, pay isn't too good and raises are non-existent unless you're being promoted, WF is definitely a "work HARDER not SMARTER" company - doesn't value education - they make you start from the bottom and work your way up regardless your experience or education

pros: I enjoyed helping our customers in the team environment at Wells Fargo.  Built some good friendships with coworkers during my years here that will likely last for years to come.
cons: The office’s temperature was nearly freezing most of the time in our suite.  Complaints about this matter made little to no impact.  Pay and benefits were average at best.  Saw some good employees leave the company because they felt micromanaged.

pros: Good pay, good exposure, sometimes you get good coworkers at your branch.
cons: High-pressure, fixed hours, competitive, too much sales not enough actual finance. Know that is very similar to any other retail job, but the products you push are financial ones.

review_title: Wells Fargo provides great opportunities for advancement
job_title: Senior Project Manager in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Comprehensive mentoring from direct managers and transparency from leadership on strategic direction. Amazing pay and benefits. For those who complain about the company or their position, I encourage you to actively manage your development and career goals. There are literally thousands of active job postings at Wells Fargo.
cons: The only con would be the high level of government regulation that makes it more difficult for a truly agile approach.

pros: Education, Benefits, Compensation, Training, Career
cons: Micromanagement, Schedules, Staffing, Disorganized, Dysfunctional

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in Des Moines, IA
pros: Good management, friendly co-workers, VTO and PTO plus personal holidays on top of holidays. Tons of team work. I can go on. I know tons of people has a strong dislike for Wells Fargo but I did not have a bad experience at all. There were times when the pressure was applied fiercely - it was never for long.
cons: Bad Public Reputation. It got hard to work for Wells Fargo when they kept making the news for scandals and violating rights. It’s hard to work for a company you have to defend constantly.

pros: Excellent benefits, good pay, nice physical environment
cons: Too much stress, like high school the cliques abound, its not how great you work its who you know.

job_title: PC LAN Analyst IV in Charlotte, NC
pros: -Salary, Co-workers, travel, benefits, customers
cons:
-Nepotism
-Management could care less about their employees, only the bottom line. 
-It a truly "CYA" organization 
-Youre told its your responsibility to obtain training for any role the company places you in. Otherwise you get dinged on performance and eventually terminated.

job_title: Equity Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work life balance is good but comes at expense of compensation.
cons:
Work in WIM as an equity analyst. 

1) Sales organization that puts sales over investment outcomes or fiduciary obligation to clients. 
2) pay is poor vs other bulge bracket firms. Firm generally pays below market rates & raises are below inflation. 
3) tech systems are archaic & channels are overly bureaucratic. (Takes months for compliance approvals, 4 weeks for website access for primary job function)
4) Upper management is more interested in cutting costs to get their bonuses than well being of employees or providing living wage
5) Investment management division is disorganized & a “follower”. Competitors far more innovative.

review_title: Dealer Services Division - Good for a time
pros: Great pay and benefits, 401k matching, medical/dental/vision, bonuses. Allowed for casual dress.
cons: Started to get very stressful my last couple years there because corporate started to penny pinch everything. Mandatory 20% off shore team members for all teams that WE had to train. No company parties after first year. Company values raises and bonuses corporate wide, not just on specific division which means even though we were super profitable we didn't get rewarded for it. Lays off happened twice since I was there.

review_title: I hear corporate is amazing...why can't they pass that onto the Retail segment?
job_title: Registered Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Benefits, if you use them. A lot of the retail co-workers are extremely friendly knowing that they are in the same boat as everyone else...underpaid and overworked.
cons: Pretty much everything else is a downside. The sales culture is incredibly "demanding" although the company seems to promote and move along those with "questionable" sales practices. Things that are often preached are the things that are rarely followed.

job_title: Registered Premier Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Wells Fargo has created many career opportunities for advancement.  While working there, Wells Fargo paid my way through college to obtain a degree in finance. Wells Fargo Bank also gave the opportunity of taking my securities licenses to further advance in my career. Wells Fargo also compensates you with incentives like bonuses if you make and exceed your sales quota quarterly.  They offer lots of benefits including 401k match up, medical, dental and vision insurance.
cons: One of the the downsides of working for Wells Fargo Bank is the amount of sales pressure put forth to the employees.

pros: The pay was very good and the health benefits were decent. 401K match up to 6%.  PTO was wonderful--20 days your first year--and if you were not in sales, it was easy to use. Co-workers were overall friendly.
cons: In my department there was no way to move up in the company. With the trouble in the financial industry, morale was getting very low. People in sales positions may not make their quotas if they used their PTO.

job_title: Financial Consultant IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is a very well-run, well-respected, and stable financial institution with lots of very smart people.  Since there are many lines of business, there are always opportunities to try different business lines or functional areas.
cons: The hours can be pretty long depending on the department that you are in.  Also, the culture can vary quite a bit from department to department - some are very conservative.

review_title: Wells turned a good company into a horrible place to work
pros: Good technology and open architecture in terms of products offerred compared to other firms.  Management pretty much lets you run your business your own way.
cons: horrible back office, Wells fed lies to FA's during buyout, horrible comp plan compared to other programs, they haircut every product and have lower grid payouts, no support from management, a 5 year old could do that job

pros:
Job security - very difficult to get fired
Opportunities to transfer into a wide variety of positions and locations
Open culture - generally easy to talk to people regardless of their job level
Good benefits and lots of time off
cons:
It's a large corporation, so it's full of bureaucracy and politics
Compensation lower than at some competitors
Not a lot of prestige working at a bank these days

review_title: Retail banking has gone down the tubes.
pros: Wells provides decent pay and benefits without having a bachelor's degree, flexible time off and great training.
cons: The sales goals are unreachable without cheating the customers. The focus for 2010 seems to be to pack as many sales people in the branches as possible, even if there is no desk for them to sit out. Constant harrassing by tellers and bankers has led many customers to flee to less aggressive banks.

pros: The opportunities at Wells Fargo make it one of the best places to grow from within.  Wells Fargo gives you the tools to make your career grow.
cons: One of the problems with Wells Fargo is the lack of openess when it comes to looking at applicants.  If you don't have direct experience in one area they will not consider you for the position.

review_title: Satisfying, but not much room for growth.
pros:
* Good vacation and benefits, and 401(k) match
* Co-workers are like family
* Our building is very nretty with nice views
cons:
* Very political, it depends on 'who you know' to get promoted
* Communications are random and all over the place, there is no consistent messaging

review_title: WF is a very stable, traditional company filled with honorable, value driven employees.
pros:
Teamwork is strong.
Employees are hard working, committed to community.
cons: Culture is very distrustful- lots of micro-management by middle and senior division managers. De-centralized control away from corporate hub leads to lack of efficiency, duplicity in efforts across company, very high bureacratic sludge to wade through day to day. Not the right company for a visionary or risk taker.

review_title: Management left much to be desired.
pros: Only as an income position until a better opportunity comes up, not a company that one would commit to in the long run.
cons: Management is absolutely disrespectful, company promotes most supervisors based on friendships formed between co-workers, one supervisor was hired simply because she was a next door neighbor to a current manager at the bank.

pros: The pros are great pay, great benefits and the career growth opportunities.  It is a very results driven  company.  Best companies for LGBT Equality.
cons: Call center environment - Tied down to the phones.  Lots of metrics to make pay outs for bonuses. You deal with a lot of irate customers.

review_title: If you love the high pressure environment, this would be one of the better sales jobs.
pros: The benefits are pretty great. Promotion are frequent and the pay is not too bad. Most importantly, you can learn a lot with little job experience.
cons: A very numbers oriented jobs. If you don't meet the metrics, upper management will look strongly down upon you and don't forget the laughable "WOW" treatment to customers. It's ridiculous.

review_title: Good learning experience with many opportunities to learn, but may not be the right long term career for everybody.
pros: Stable company, strong leadership, technologically advanced (compared to other banks), supportive of career development, supportive of community involvement, strong emphasis on training/learning, decentralized nature offers more opportunities to advance, culture is focused on customers, work/life balance is respected.
cons: Very conservative, so it can be slow to change, decentralized nature can mean unnecessary bureaucratic issues, pay structure results in top performers being underpaid and underperformers being overpaid, lack of financial support for pursuit of advanced degrees.

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great place to work
pros: It is a challenging job working with great people.  Wells offers a treat your job like you own it philosophy.  They also offer good benefits and flexible hours.  Lower level management does a very good job creating a positive work environment.  As long as you do your work nobody will be looking over your shoulder.
cons: There is limited upward mobility. You are working in a niche market so opportunities to advance using the skills from this job with other companies are limited.

review_title: Money's ok but not worth it at all!
pros: Decent money and quarterly incentives
cons: Managers only care about numbers and even if you do good one day the next day you'll be taken into a back room and screamed at for hours. Nearly impossible sales goals, and customer service surveys that only count if you get a PERFECT score on 5 questions. The surveys are given days after the customer was in the store and sometime would surveys the wrong person but it would still count against you AND your entire store. SO that means if you get 4 out of 5 it equals 0. If this happens your fellow employees will be pissed because their bonuses will be taken away. Horrible, stressful and demeaning work environment.

review_title: Stable employment but little opportunity to advance
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The firm has extensive market share and is part of one of the most solid American banks.  This allows the firm to have tremendous resources and name recognition.
cons: There is little value given to strategic thinking, or to any kind of thinking at all, for that matter.  Rote processing and strict adherence to policy are all that really matters in this environment.  Like any large bureaucracy, many processes confound the most basic common sense and leave those with half of a brain baffled.

pros:
The people I worked with were dedicated to their jobs and we did a good job. Several accolades for independent departments in licensing as well as licensing as a whole.
Our department had a good manager.
cons:
When Wells Fargo took over, everything changed. As First Union, and Wachovia, the company was family and employee oriented. Wells Fargo took away our Family Care time, our pension, Wells Fargo is for Wells Fargo.
Outsourced our dept.

review_title: You are nothing more than a number
pros: Strong name, walk-ins, teller leads, lots of opportunity to move into other positions and/or departments
cons: The sales goals are extremely high and overly aggressive. Management does not care about the customer they are exclusively concerned with selling as many products as possible, even if they don't need them. Questionable sales practices, very high turnover which is evident when the customer tells you "every time I walk into the bank there are new people working here"

job_title: Pesonal Banker I in Jackson, WY
pros: Great training and reputation.   Super place to start your banking career, but the pay will not come if you have started at the bottom.  You will need to move outside of the Co. to be financially rewarded.
cons: Too big, too inflexible.  The amount of red tape and layers of mgt. is unreal!  You will be frustrated with this in your personal experience and on the customers behalf.  Cutting out some of the "stuff" would be good for both employees and customers.

review_title: Could be, should be, but is not great
pros: Name brand, products, Software, pop machine has good selection, marketing implemented years ago still stands strong today (see cons), don't have to pay for parking, the provide lunch once per year (sales)
cons: Leadership, pay, benefits in Minnesota, zero consideration from people doing all the work, nothing new from marketing just more people telling you what to do who have never sold anything in there current job let alone a mortgage.

pros:
They are great with working around your schedule.
They offer full benefits even for part time employees and the match up to 6% on your 401k.
Commission on Sales.
cons:
They are way too hard on employees when it comes to sales. Its really pushy.
There isn't a unified understanding between all Wells Fargo branches. One branch will have a bunch of different rules and policies when compared to the branch across town.

pros: Paid training and a lot of paid time off. A lot of support to learn the company and procedures
cons: Promote minorities even when they don't deserve it, some employee get frustrated with you very quickly when you are new, they only care about sales...you can be the biggest jerk but if you can get sales they don't care. Management can be snobby and have an "us" and "them" attitude.

pros:
Great training
Benefits package incl tuition reimbursement
cons: Aggressive sales culture from mgmt, more about widgets and quantity than quality relationships with clients on retail side. (Private bank side exact opposite.)

pros:
Schedule working the 9-5 dream
Getting the holidays off
cons:
Management cram sales goals down your throat granted I had no problems with hitting them but what you do today or last month gets thrown out the next day.
Mind numbing morning meetings everyday coming in the half our early to cover same thing everyday....
Hours upon hours of work and being the dictatorship of service managers that go on power trips
Branch manager that and I quote if my friends and family didn't open up accounts with wells they weren't really my friends or family.
Overall worst experience ever, every position is underpaid for the hoops and loops you have to hop to satisfy the management till the next day.. and quarterly "Gold" bonus is a joke

review_title: Visions and Values are not practiced at retail level
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Reading, PA
pros: Excellent, in depth training for new employees.
cons: Aggressive, cut throat sales expectations straddle the line of what is ethical/unethical.  Employees are encouraged to solicit every customer whether or not a sale is in that customer's best interest.  Upper management uses scare tactics daily to increase sales solutions

review_title: Amazing company to work for, unachievable sales goals!!
job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Scottsdale, AZ
pros: Wells Fargo offers amazing medical and dental benefits, plenty of vacation time, volunteer time, and banking benefits. They are flexible when it comes to scheduling and are willing to train their team members to move up the chain.
cons: Promotions are harder to achieve because of unachievable sales goals across all sections. Sales pressure and constant reminders of sales is sickening and depressing. Do not work for Wells if you are not a sales person because that's all they care about. Higher management, outbound sales call nights, no overtime.

pros: Personable Management. Helpful atmosphere. Opportunity to grow. Flexible hours. I went to school during my stint and they were supportive with my schedule and class work.
cons: Heavy focus on sales. At certain times. the position can become tedious. Like with any customer facing business, you will deal with a variety of good and bad customers. At the very least, it teaches you how to be diplomatic. The staff seems always have your back.

review_title: Worked part time while in school
pros: Opportunity for internal growth as long as you meet and/or exceed goals
cons: Large sales goals. When you meet and exceed goals you are rewarded and then the requirement increases significantly

review_title: Relaxed work environment with an emphasis on production over quality. Poor hiring decisions when it came to management.
job_title: Consumer Loan Underwriter II in Birmingham, AL
pros: Pay was decent. Environment was relaxed as long as you hit your production expectations.
cons: Management by intimidation was very common and it took knowing the right people in order to get promoted. Mandatory Saturday overtime (up to 8 hours) was very common. Layoffs were also common and it was common for management to divert attention from layoff rumors.

review_title: It had it's benefits as well as it's drawbacks.
pros: As a national organization focused on profitability, shareholders, and production, it had some benefits.  The fringe benefits like medical, dental, etc. were good for the employee.
cons: Large national organization made decisions nationally that didn't apply to local area and micro-managed to increase shareholder benefit and profitability while employees were mostly worked harder and harder.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
1) My direct managers were almost always excellent
2) Compensation and benefits are competitive
3) Work environment was pleasant
4) I generally worked with really smart (and fun) people
5) Flexible work arrangements are often possible for the FT office staff
6) The company itself has a great reputation, so solid experience here is a real resume builder
cons:
1) Instability - lots of reorgs - not sure when one of them might knock you right out of a job
2) Competitive culture - difficult to move up in the organization

review_title: Difficult to close loans on time
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Annandale, VA
pros: Great benefits and very visible name for consumers. Internal harp and FHA streamline refinances are fairly easy to do and to find customers to do them for.  Excellent jumbo rates
cons: Terrible processing and underwriting. Nearly impossible to hit closing dates on time.  Loan officers are treated poorly, processors and underwriters run the show. Realtors hate the company and very few will agree to work with you and often times listing agents will not take your pre approval letters seriously

job_title: Assistant Vice President, Communications Consultant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The company truly believes in being a positive influence in the community. They give a lot to charity. Good benefits, including time off for volunteering. They make very effort to remind you what a great company it is to work for.
cons: Very controlling of expenses. Justification is required for any spending. Down to the nickel. When joining the company, negotiate for the biggest salary possible. Once you are on the team, the raises will be less than the regular increase in health care.

review_title: Good Company to Work For, Sales Culture Not For All
pros: Great corporate culture of inclusion and progressive values. Good people at its core. Plenty of opportunities to move forward in the company.
cons: Very strong sales culture. There is a temptation to cut corners or to resort to less than honest means to get the numbers that are expected. Seems to always be pushing a boulder up hill.

review_title: Only good if you can put it past you to befriend people only to reach numbers. Not what I believe in
pros: Good pay, 401k is set up really well, it is a bank after all... Good vacation time, flexible with school.
cons: Everything. Management is terrible. Every day is a bad day and there's never satisfaction no matter how many sales you get. Even if you reach your highest sales goal for the quarter, they still want more. These people have no moral compass, befriending people to reach numbers is in no way honest to me.

pros: Good hours because they are flexible and easy to work with.  Great company to have on your resume because it is worldwide known as a strong brand.
cons: Not the best pay I could have been paid better given the situation.  I feel like advancement was a bit difficult and things could have been one better.

pros: The risk management space has seen a lot of opportunities open up. This makes Wells Fargo an appealing place for those interested in risk management.
cons: A lot of changes within the risk management  field comes with a lot of uncertainty. This however, is not unexpected since risk management in banking has evolved significantly in the aftermath of the financial crisis of 2008

pros: Started out great ! Great management , employees , same loyal customers !
cons:
Then managers left , officers left , tellers left !!  Only 3 tellers still there ! Now every time I go in there new staff including Mngrs !!! At this branch !???? Why ???  
Less & less customers ! Hiring totally clueless people ! V sad ! High end suburb urban branch ! What is going on here !??????

review_title: Can be a great company to work for if you have a deal of patience and can overlook ignorant people.

job_title: Home Loan Processor in Tempe, AZ

review_title: Working full time you HAVE to love your job!
pros:
Wells Fargo is hands down the best place I have EVER worked for. If I had an actual interest in banking as a career, I would undoubtedly stay with this company for my entire life. Management works hand in hand with you to help you succeed. Upper management makes regular visits to the branches to check in on the staff and assist us in moving up. Believe me, if you are ambitious and a hard worker, there is no way NOT to do well with this company. You don't necessarily need to have any sort of degree either. If someone were to start out at Wells with just a high school diploma, you can still easily move up. Simply do well! Pay attention, ask questions, provide customer service, and SMILE. It's that simple. AND, Wells Fargo has a GREAT tuition reimbursement program for it's employees, so if you get a job you can educate yourself to better your career with them after one year and they'll pick up the tab!
Wells Fargo really, truly, cares about their employees. The pay is great, especially for an entry level position! Working for a large company such as Wells Fargo offers great job security too. While our economy is doing so poorly, this is a very important aspect of a prospective job. As other banks continue to downsize, Wells Fargo is increasing it's profits. It pays to be helpful too. The incentive pay for sales and customer service is great. There are so many different ways to get bonuses on your paychecks! Catch a fraudulent transaction, get a bonus. Have top customer surveys for the quarter, get a bonus. Achieve a very low sales goal, get a bonus. 
It's easy to get overtime too. There are always branches around that are going to be short staffed. Tell your manager that you are interested in getting some overtime, and they will send you to another branch to help them be staffed accordingly.
cons: As any customer service position, you have to deal with some very unruly customers from time to time. Especially dealing with something as personal as someone's money. Explaining why someone is dirt poor to them is never enjoyable. Though, this is not central  to Wells Fargo. You will find this in any banking position.

pros: Wells Fargo is a great place to start your career, I was promoted very quickly. If you enjoy a fast paced work environment, dealing with people, and meeting challenging goals then Wells Fargo is great. The management team is competent and so are the training programs.
