review_title: Very good company to work for!
pros: Great benefits. Constantly training you on new and improved programs in order to make you successful. Easy to get promoted if you're one of their best. Also they are really good about transferring you when you need to.
cons: Some managers, not all, are very micromanaging. You are also tracked on EVERYTHING you do, or in most cases don't do. So if you're truly a slacker, you won't last long.

review_title: If you're looking for a entry level position in Banking, Wells Fargo is for you.
job_title: Personal Banker in Mountain View, CA
pros:
- Commercial Banking Industry Experience 
- Fast Paced environment 
- Health, Dental, PTO Benefits
cons:
- Middle Management bias 
- Micro-managing of all employees
- Little to no job growth 
- Hostile corporate culture created from fierce competition within bankers
- No support from Banking store manager or District Manager

pros: With consolidation of AG Edwards, Wachovia, and Wells' previous, potential to be a really special firm is evident. With solid hold of the mortgage market share leadership many things are in place to be a revenue monster!
cons: Having been with AG, the advent of quotas, increased fees, and FAs being tasked with a mortgage quota kind of soured my stay. Many long time clients also never got accustomed to new firm.

review_title: What was once a good company Wachovia is working on destroying
job_title: Investment Banking Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Used to be a great place to work. Used to have great benefits. Used to value it's older employees.
cons: Health benefits offered not great. If someone doesn't do well in the company they promote them to management instead of training them properly or simply firing them.

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Irvine, CA
pros: Senior management, vision, technology, client base, Conservative banking business model.  Stability and compensation are ok.  Solid benefits to include 401k and medical.
cons: Micro management.  Skill set of middle management suspect as best.  Limited independent thought; recommendations for efficiency frowned upon.  Turn over and attrition excessive even by financial services standards.  Aggressive sales culture.  Middle management strategy reactionary as opposed to prescriptive.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Littleton, CO
pros: Great environment.  Wells Fargo employees are so friendly and helpful naturally.  I've made best friends here and it's so easy to ask for advice or sales tips.  Also, bonuses and promotion opportunities are huge and can happen quickly if you do the job right!
cons: Very ,very sales driven and competitive.  Training for a banker is a month long, but you are still expected to meet the regular quarterly goal even though you aren't out selling or at a desk for a 1/3 of it.

review_title: It helps to get in the right department
job_title: Manager in West Des Moines, IA
pros:
1. Generous Paid Time Off
2. Flexible Scheduling
3. Good work environment
cons: Limited advancement potential uless you are in the "Right" department or know someone.  Less benefits than when I started over 10 years ago.  Horrible job search process.

review_title: Great learning experience & people friendly work environment
pros: Good work life balance, competitive salary, opportunity to work in different teams and in different verticals, fair people policies, best part is no restriction on using personal emails or social networking sites
cons: Not a fast paced or challenging work environment, stringent dress code policy, not too flexible in terms of working hours.

job_title: PCG Brokerage Client Associate in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Wells Fargo is a great company and has provided me with 16+ years of career opportunities.  I left after 14 years, took a year off and went back - lost my tenure, but the company is great, so I am starting over again!  Benefits are competitive and the corportate culture is great
cons: Small pay increases; average of 3-5% per year.  Only way for increases is to change business lines or quit and go back

review_title: Good, physically responsible company with good ideals.
pros: Not sure if pay for people coming in is good, but the benefits are good and the pay was fair for the job expectations.
cons: Training is non-existent.  Time off can be hard to get, leadership is all over the map although the ideals are in the right place.  Not consistent w/ expectations and rewards.  Front Line management is thrown in and employees under them suffer for their lack of training and how the do or do not deal effectively with employees

review_title: Sales oriented culture, at the expense of the customer
pros: Plenty of capital resources, competent management, decent salary
cons: Sacrifice of customer for profit, loss of collegial environment (I was Legacy Wachovia), somewhat cutthroat.

job_title: Personal Banker I (SAFE) in Flagstaff, AZ
pros: Great Benefit package and opportunity for growth
cons: Sales are pushed to the point of relentlessness. High Turnover for Tellers and Personal Bankers

job_title: Premier Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Lots of experience working with diverse products and services. Including retail and investment products and working with personal and business clients. Clients make the work much better as you get to build relationships with the people you work with.
cons: Old fashioned polices make it difficult and get what you want in your region. Many times an employee will have the apply out of their market to advance their career.

review_title: Had so many interviews (on the phone). They would forget, or just never call back. Until the one time I called back.
pros: When I called back they allowed me to come in for a face to face. After a week I found out I was chosen to be hired. Good not to long, not to short interview process, make you feel comfortable during interview , down to earth recruiting staff, not long before I stated working :)
cons: Changed my training class 3 days before I started, other than that none.

pros: There is no pros with this company they let a drug addict run there sites
cons: There sites are horrible some sites don't have restrooms u would have to pee outside they lie about your pay starting at your orientation The manger treat different races a certain way basically ur working with pure racism sad but true they had one great manger Gary Vich other then that its Not worth your time or energy

job_title: Personal Banker I in Arcadia, CA
pros: Great products and training program, opportunity for advancement, community involvement and professional environment.
cons: Base pay for branch employees is not that great and while you can make commission, you are placed under enormous sales pressure and if you dont meet all your sales goals, you receive ZERO commission for your hard work.  The only thing that matters to this company is generating more sales and taking more money from the public.

review_title: Great company, great benefits but will lay people off
pros: 6% company match on 401k. Offer both Roth and Traditional 401k. No pension plan. I think you'd like working here especially if you stay away from retail.
cons: I heard the retail side is awful. I would avoid that at all costs. Their goals are unattainable and they will fire you when you don't reach them.

job_title: Lead Teller in Los Angeles, CA
pros: A lot of customer coming in for great service that this bank provides, esp when you are on high end districts such as Beverly Hills, Santa Monica etc.  They have coffee vending machine for customers, bottled water, chocolates etc. Everything just depends on how great your boss will be.
cons: Easy to get promoted as long as your doing good in your performance your meeting you sales goals and Wow  customer service surveys.

job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in Bethlehem, PA
pros: Decent base salary and some benefits
cons: Everything else. They train you in class for 4 weeks before attempting the job then when you begin to do the job they tell you that everything learned in that training was incorrect. Then, you are forced to relearn the entire job with many more contradictions to follow. Their form of 'motivation' is to yell at you until you do it right with intentionally unreachable sales goals. Unreachable sales goals also means, that you will NEVER meet your sales incentive bonus. Extremely disappointed with this company and it's values.

review_title: A company that wants to help its employees succeed in life
pros: The vast amount of training and information that Wells Fargo has to offer its employees in amazing. Their training is great. They do not just expect their employees to know everything. They do expect a lot out of their employees, but if one falls direction and wants to learn they can succeed.
cons: They company does have high expectations for every employee, even for newbies. The learning curve can be difficult, but if you follow direction, you will do great!

review_title: Company has lowered their standards in the type of personnel they hire and promote in recent years.
pros: I had a flexible schedule at the time which is nearly impossible to have now. Good benefits and tuition reinbursemet is available. You learn a lot about sales and customer service standards.
cons: Bad management, unrealistic sales goal everyday, poor sales ethics, favoritism and lots of gossip in every office.

review_title: Depends on the manager at your branch
job_title: Customer Service and Sales Representative in District Heights, MD
pros: Enjoyed working at the branch where I started. Was a teller for six months and was promoted to platform,, although sell sell sell is the all time priority it's less pressuring if you're in a branch where the manager is more relaxed. The idea of selling products and services to customers that don't need or desire them is not right.  Customers aren't number one.
cons: All about meeting metrics. Does not cater to customers needs

pros: Great company to be associated with, great training programs, good benefits, limited possibility of growth unless you are part of the "Clan".
cons: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage could be the best in the lending industry. Unfortunately, their management choices are very weak to say the least, upper management has NO clue when it comes to hiring or advancing their branch managers. During my tenure with the company approximate twelve months, I endured a total of FIVE managers, one worse and less qualified than the other, totally clueless. Micromanagement does NOT work in this business!

review_title: Great company to work for if you want to start building a career.
job_title: Service Manager II in Bothell, WA
pros:
- Fairly comprehensive benefits
- Good opportunity to move within the company upward and laterally across the US
- Company is constantly trying to move towards excellent customer service over sales
cons:
- Manager positions lack work life balance from what I've seen
- Base pay low compared to competitors or similarly placed positions.

pros: Big company with good intentions but have challenges  - If you like big large company good spot for you.
cons: Views of employees from management is that they are all replaceable.  No hard feelings it's just bad business in my opinion

review_title: Poor Management from top to bottom
job_title: Bankruptcy Specialist I in Fort Mill, SC
pros:
Big name corporation
Other opportunities within Wells Fargo
cons: Wells Fargo (more specifically the Home Mortgage division) is very poorly managed.  The management and lower level employees shift so often that the departments are constantly shuffling to change processes that don't need changing, and insist on keeping outdated ones that do need changing.

pros:
Great position to gain experience in supervision of wealth management. 
Highly invovled in audit preparation and risk supervision
Firm has a culture focused on client service and risk mitigation
cons:
This postion can very greatly depending upon the Admin managers view of scope of duties (the position can lack challenges if the Admin Manager has difficulties delegating tasks)
There is also a lack of structured training within this postion

pros: Flexible work environment; family friendly in most Lines of Business
cons: Being so big, most jobs represent a small cog in a monstrous wheel -- so individual input and recognition tends to get lost.  Health plan was recently (~2012) changed for the worse and is not getting better (like many other large companies)

pros: Always got my hours. Steady dependable job.
cons: Sales goals were mostly unattainable. Managers were terrible. I had a manager whisper behind me "fail" while I was with a customer. The pressure to do sales was so intense there were days that I felt I was going to have a melt down.

pros: Good team experience. You really get to know the people you work with and a good manager makes you feel like you have an input to the quality of the branch.
cons: The sales goal system does not seem right. A lot of it comes down to luck and many employees do not take part in ethical sales and get rewarded for doing so.

pros: Laid back environment, pay is ok,  PTO is pretty good as well, they gave me an option of going part time to go to school.
cons: Micro managing and customers yelling/cursing at me stressed me out the most. Training could be better and I say that because I've been told two different things to a customer based off manager or team lead input that caused them to get angry. It actually happened more than once. Also I've been taught certain things in training that would be opposite in team meetings which is really confusing.

pros: decent pay, steady hours, no weekends. can sometimes be an easy job depending on the day and time of year. most days aren't bad, you sometimes get a rude customer her and there but that's normal
cons: rude management, no room for growth, company doesn't care about its workers. and if you don't like to interact with the public this is not the job for you.

pros: Fast paced environment, always something to do, start off with 18 days of paid vacation time and it does roll over. Paid Holidays and ability to work around schedule. Offer volunteer hours.
cons: While there is room for development, you really have to know someone in order to get a promotion. Very discouraging. I spent a year and a half as a teller and had numerous open ended promises saying that I would be promoted.

review_title: I haven't started yet, but the people I've met along the way have been amazing.
job_title: Financial Crimes Specialist III in Charlotte, NC
pros: The CIC building has shops, hair and nail salon, Barber shop, dentist and doctor office, tax preparers, restaurants, etc! It's everything you'd want out of a work environment. And you get 4 weeks of PTO your first year! And any hours worked after 4pm, they give you an extra 15% added to your hourly rate!
cons: Late hours. Not intended as a job for families. I can't think of any more cons, but I'm quite new.

job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Competitive salary that can be negotiated. Numbers driven company if you perform you can move up fast. Build lasting relationships with clientele.
cons: Numbers driven company so if you underperform one day they act like the world is going to end. The retail side of the bank is a trap, you can move up fast to manager if your good but that's about it.

review_title: Do it and Regret it- Pleasanton,CA Gateway Location
pros:
Great Benefits *if you are willing to sell your soul"
Feedback galore (only way to learn)
cons:
-Gossipy and family like crew already developed
-Being drawn into the drama if you wanna be involved and have "nice" work relationships
-Little care for rules, regulations and NATIONAL laws....as long as the job gets done and you are sending people to talk about products with the Banker
-Negative attitudes
-Incorrect lessons on how to cross-sell and then get yelled at when you don't do it correctly
- Cheesy ending scripts that the customers view as fake and annoying

review_title: Not a good company to work for
job_title: Anonymous Employee in South River, NJ
pros: Employee benefits were good.
cons: Over worked and under paid. They only care about numbers. SELL SELL SELL. They give employees unrealistic goals, and have lost the caring about the people aspect of the company that Wachovia had. Understandable that the numbers matter, but without the people, where is the business really going.

review_title: Love the job not the numbers
pros: Helping customers on a personal level is amazing you can really make a difference by going out of your way to make their banking more convenient. Technology is very up to date! Almost all teller work is paperless. Fairly easy to move up in the company.
cons: You are required to have a financial conversation with every single customer you help. Minimum sales for tellers a quarter is 70 solutions. Surveys every week can really make or break your day if customers do not put all "5"

pros: The people who work there are generally great people who want to best for the customers.
cons: There can be a lot of pressure to hit sales goals that may be a tad unrealistic. Be weary of inter office politics. There is a lot to be said by "is who you know..."

review_title: It was overall an ok job.
pros: The benefits were great! The training they give you is hands on and you learn everything you need to know in the 6 weeks of training!
cons: The scheduling and new training classes were ridiculous! If your child is sick or something bad goes wrong with your family and you need to change schedules you are out of luck!! And having to sell a product to every caller was crazy! They got annoyed as well!

job_title: Personal Banker in Vero Beach, FL
pros: 401k and paid time off
cons: Pay should equal experience and for work performed. Not as good as it could be. Employees would work harder and smarter for a better base pay then killing themselves for the incentive that doesn't pay enough and asked for your first born. (Sarcasim) And you definitely have to suck up to management  (whether if its sleeping with them or doing sexual favors in the parking lot like other bankers) for a raise! Hopefully not all branches are like that but within this district they are. Please be careful.

pros: Location convenient and near major highways training runs for 3 weeks and they try to make sure that you have a good understanding of your position before they release you on your own this is a plus for the company
cons: Pay is less than what I originally expected for company this size. I chose  Wells Fargo because of the brand and what it stands for and I feel that with hard work I will eventually get promoted and have the potential to earn the income that I deserve

pros: Great benefits package with 401k, health, and dental, and other things that could be useful, Paid training, Easy to move up if you apply yourself
cons: They put a lot of pressure on everyone to make sales and you get in trouble for not meeting sales goals, the rules of the company are not consistent. Some people make up their own rules and if you are not a higher-up, you must follow them. Mostly just the sales ethics were horrible. Not surprised they are getting sued.

pros: Wells Fargo has been really good to me. I've grown a lot and there is always opportunity for advancement.
cons: Not all teams are created equal. It's hard to go from an established team to a new struggling team. Retail turnover is high. Almost everyone is moving up (as opposed to leaving), but it always seems like there are new people who aren't always experienced.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Yorba Linda, CA
pros: High energy, customer centric, and warm atmosphere. They will teach you how to advance in any area of the bank if you ask and are persistent.
cons: There was some sales pressure, but they are fixing the problem now. As they transition into the, "what is next for Wells Fargo period," there is a lot of murkiness to any career advancement and company policies.

pros: If you want to stay in retail banking (teller, service manager, or banker) they'll help you grow towards that goal but it often takes awhile.
cons: If you don't want to stay in retail banking it is very hard to get any other job within Wells Fargo and you are not able to apply out unless you have been in your current position for a year.

job_title: Operations Processor II in Irving, TX
pros: The schedule is very flexiable, the days Monday thru Friday. I think not having to work on weekends is a plus. Overtime is offered for those who want to work it. I also like the job because it is not working on the phones its mostly data.
cons: The management style is more a dicatorship and not a leadership. The company is  real big on buddy buddy if you know this boss you get special treatment. The work you live slaves with litlle pay. A very stressful work enviornment.

pros: Great benefits including 401k and amazing paid time off.  Health and dental is also really good. They also give you service hours where you can volunteer and not lose pay which is very generous.
cons: There isn't a lot of salary increase with this position, especially if you are not licensed. It is typically just a cost of living increase which is next to nothing.

review_title: Great culture, great employee engagement, Great Management
pros: Culture, employee engagement, employee development, benefits, trained and competent leadership.
cons: Had an issue I brought up to the HR hotline and the vibe was very pro management protection and employee belittlement.  I experienced this well before the companies legal fallout and came to understand after the fact that this behavior permeated the upper echelons of the company.

pros: I started above minimum wage
cons: The company is built strongly behind getting the sale to the customer instead of, putting each individual's needs first.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Des Moines, IA
pros:
Very general benefits package. (401K match, time off, maternity/paternity leave)
Great work/life balance.
Large company with many opportunities for advancement.
Very established company history.
Great charitable donations and corporate social responisbility.
cons:
Large company with many channels of approval needed to implement change.  
Slow to adopt new technologies in some of the non core segments.

pros: Despite recent negative news from bank channel, the senior management of WFA is top quality. They truly have a "put client first" attitude. My job, working with clients all day long, is highly rewarding. I've enjoyed working with the same clients for over 15 years, getting to know their families.
cons: Downside would be the ever growing regulatory requirements that makes being productive more difficult and complicated. But I believe WFA has responded with tools and technology to make it as easy as possible, but that said, it's still challenging.

review_title: Autonomous and there is growth for how ever hard you want to push yourself.
pros: My manager was very relaxed and didn't micro manage also there are many options to grow.
cons: As a contractor, had to take 10 days of mandatory time off. Unsure if a full time position will be available.

pros: Great benefits and rewards. That gives you the initiative to keep your job.
cons: They ask so much of you whether you are a teller, manager, service manager.  You have to 'fit in' if you want respect from the management all the way around. So much change in rules, regulations, it's very difficult to keep up and do as they ask.

pros: A great place to work at one time. Proud of our individual business (which was far removed from retail bank). Overall, great support of team members until negative market practices relevelations started coming out.
cons: Centralization of marketing department created  bureaucratic nightmare. Too many people jockeying for ownership. No longer focused on doing what's best for the business each marketing team is supposed to be supporting. Paralysis. Projects moved at glacial pace.  In addition, multiple negative business practices continue to haunt business prompting multiple rounds of layoffs.

review_title: Amazing benefits and care about customer experience
job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Greeley, CO
pros: Great benefits and they really make an effort to take care of their team members
cons: Trying to find the balance between still wanting sales and building customer relationships, sometimes the direction of the company can be lost in translation. Not flexible hours at all

pros: Wells Fargo as a company has great values, benefits and really strives to keep its employees as its competitive advantage.
cons: Management doesn’t check in on it’s front line managers to ensure they are driving the same message and completing accurate training and work life balance.

review_title: Terrible company- no room to move up
job_title: Securities Operations Service Specialist in Richmond, VA
pros:
-Dept allowed me to choose my shift
-Tons of time off and 4 month maternity and 3 month paternity leave
cons:
-No room for advancement. Dept leaders do not allow you to move to another dept and you do not make enough money to justify staying
-EXTREME pressure for quality and quantity on production. You stare at three computer screens all day and have to track every time you walk to the bathroom, eat, speak to a friend for a moment, send an email... The most micromanaged I've been in my entire life.

review_title: If you do not like to sell, sell, sell.......then you will hate working for Wells Fargo
pros: Good benefits.  Most coworkers are nice people.
cons: The attitude around here is......if you are not a relationship manager or banker then you do not add any value.  You are treated as if you are not needed if you are not bringing in business and clearly adding directly to the bottom line.

review_title: Great place to gain experience if you are committed to working in a retail branch setting.
pros: Wells Fargo offers tuition reimbursement and is a great place work while attending school.  Unfortunately it seems as though the experience gained has little relevence outside of the financial services arena.
cons: It is a very competitive sales environment in which senior management gives a tremendous amount of pressure.  Economic conditions set aside, you are still required to hit all sales goals.

review_title: Good people but Wachovia needs to find the its nich in I-banking.
pros: I iked the junior people, and some senior management. The pay package is relatively good, and the city of Charlotte is a great place for young professionals.
cons: The orginization means well, but the bank tries to be like a traditiona buldge bracket firm and this is not Wachovia's strong point.

pros: they give you extensive training to do your job...and there are so many opportunities with wells fargo...also there are people to help you when you need it.
cons: there are not to many cons with wells Fargo it's a great company to work for but if I had to put one it would be the loss of trust with customers have with banks at this time.

review_title: Good Place to work if you're focused and willing to work hard.
job_title: Personal Banker I in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
- Performance based promotions
- Plenty of positions available for advancement
- Great benefits
- Great vacation time
- Great training
cons:
- Daily sales quotas
- High pressure sales environment
- Will be pressured to open accounts for family and friends
- You are only as good as your  numbers (not always a bad thing)
- Must operate in the gray area in order to hit your quotas

review_title: Good Place to Work. Great bonuses!
job_title: Senior Credit Manager in Mobile, AL
pros: Very attainable goals.  Great people to work with.  They are very positive and give recognition when deserved.  Great Vcp (commission).  You will learn to sell!  If you don't mind cold calling this is the job for you!  Strong Company.
cons: Growth within the company is possible but there are few manager positions available so you may need to move in order to advance in your career depending on your location

pros: Really good benefits. Decent pay. Pretty high for someone with no banking expierence whatsoever. Decent hours.
cons: Super stressed about sales. Also training was very concentrated on customer service, not product. So now I'm sitting there trying to help people open accounts and products that I don't know that much more about than they do.

review_title: Good to spend the rest of life with basic contributions. Advancement and opportunities are reserved for the selective.
pros: Work-life balance is something you can get if you are smart and efficient and can do the minimal required for the job.
cons: You are not really developing skills, you cannot be honest in your feedback about progress and you have go with the flow.

review_title: Hard job, but can be a good platform to work at a secure institution
job_title: Personal Banker I in Denver, CO
pros: Wells Fargo is a great place to work because of its positive management, and amazing benefits.  It allows you to also grow within the company, assuming you have a strong work ethic.
cons: Daily sales goals are challenging and wear on you.  The managers tend to micromanage if sales goals are not exceeded each day.

pros: Stable job, you know what you are required to do. At times, it can feel a bit rah rah rah, but overall I was proud to work for this prestigeous company . Very work hard, play hard.
cons: While they preach about being customer focused, this is a sales job through and through. My only gripe about this place was the sales focus and how hard it was pushed.

pros: It is extremely easy to get a job in collections.  The position is obviously entry-level.  There is great internal positions once you reach the one year requirement.
cons: Most managers don't know how to recognize talent.  You will be micromanaged to a T. Don't expect any freedom or any say in how things are done.

pros:
GREAT resources.
Challenging, but exciting.
Impressive benefits package.
Two weeks paid vacation & paid holidays.
Recognition for a job well done.
Regular raises (even though they're not big raises, more money is more money.)
If you want to move up in the company, follow the formula and show them you're capable, and it'll happen for you sooner than later.
Lastly, competitive products for customers. Wells Fargo doesn't fall behind in trends.
cons:
Positions at Wells Fargo are not paid as well as similar positions at other banks.
Sales focused positions are very demanding. (When I was there, it was "2 a day")

review_title: Wells is a meh place to be- great benefits and vacation, mediocre salary and myopic management
job_title: Project Manager IV in San Francisco, CA
pros: The benefits package is great, and the vacation is generous.
cons: Work since the merger has been a constant challenge, and not always in a good way. Wells seems loathe to invest in growth and instead is having teams try to do double the work (to make the integration happen) without staffing accordingly or planning long term.

review_title: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is satisfying
pros: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is a good company to work for. They were the first large bank to come out of the recession and pay back their bailout.
cons: Wells Fargo Home Mortgage is a big company, part of an even bigger Wells Fargo & Co. If you like a big company well there it is, but you might get lost in the shuffle.

review_title: A good place to work before merger with Wachovia
pros:
-- The company is doing well despite the challenges in the financial services industry and economic downturn. 
-- Typically good work/life balance.
cons: -- Too many re-orgs and chaos post merger with Wachovia that made for a very unpleasant place to work. Caused a lot of friction between the two companies that created a 'us' vs 'them' mentality.

review_title: A great start to a rewarding career
pros: They really encouraged your personal growth. Most managers wanted to promote within and would push for you if they think you deserved it.
cons: The only thing I think that was an issue with the company is how they review potential issues between employees. They tend to take the "victim's" words over anything else.

job_title: Personal Banker II in West Palm Beach, FL
pros: People are nice, environment is clean and professional, benefits are great, and most important....the part time employees are the best to work with!
cons: Management is terrible, the sales goals are not attainable, the company wants their employees to feel as if they are at a store rather than a bank!

review_title: Its a good job to start off after graduating from college
pros: Gain experience when it comes to providing customer service and learn more about the financial industry. Have the ability to move up fast.
cons: Depending on the management you have they only care about sales sales sales. It gets old after a while. I don't like when the manager comes to the desk and say heres some bad news.

pros: Wells Fargo Bank provides excellent employee health and other benefits. The Bank could provide excellent opportunities for beginning a career.
cons: Many employees experience a very top down, vindictive, often disrespectful. know it all management style.  As a result, employee morale suffers tremendously - this affects customer service (especially in former Wachovia locations).  Pay scale for many jobs appears to be low.

job_title: Project Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Decent pay, established processes & procedures.
cons: Underhanded politics and good ol' boy club mentality. Who you know and CYA is more important to management than results and efficiency.

review_title: A great experience... but would like more money
pros: Opportunity to learn the US monetary system.  A chance to grow with one of the major US banks where you have the opportunity to grow.
cons: Work Life balance.  Sometimes there are pitfalls if you are good at what you do because they have some reservations on promoting.

review_title: Benefits and company culture increasingly poor
pros: The pay and vacation time at Wells Fargo are generally pretty favorable compared to other financial services companies.  Their job ranking system makes it fairly easy to move up ranks while staying in a position that you enjoy.
cons:
The benefits and job culture at Wells Fargo are increasingly poor.  With their relentless focus on cutting costs internally, it has become a very unhappy and demoralized place to work.

Their recent and forced switch to HSA plans has caused large numbers of employees to incredibly dissatisfied.  And no wonder, when medical costs have doubled or tripled in a single year, while at the same time essentially requiring the employees to stressfully micromanage medical expenses.

job_title: EBusiness Consultant in Des Moines, IA
pros:
Benefits
People
Resources
Advancement
Education

The environment is focused on growth, both personal and corporate.  The benefits are fantastic (at least pre-Wachovia acquisition).  The environment could be stressful given the financial industry as a whole.  However, the resources, events, opportunities for advancement and other factors make Wells Fargo an outstanding place to work.  It's truly an honor to have worked at a top 100 company in the midwest.
cons:
Financial Industry
Restrictions on Communications, Marketing
Empathy for Less than Perfect Credit Customers

review_title: The pay is fair for the work performed, and there are many opportunities to telecommute.
pros: Large company with many opportunities for advancement or job change. The pay is fair, with many telecommuting opportunities. Benefits are better than avergae with matching 401k.
cons: Wells is located throughout the US , in many different time zones so meetings can be a little hard to schedule. Some tems may have to come in earlier or stay latter depending on your area.

job_title: Account Executive II in Southfield, MI
pros: Good benefits, Decent wages, access to a large data base of information.  Discounts through certain companies.  If you are not heterosexual...okay..they have same sex benefits!  Matches 6% for 401K which is awesome.
cons: Large company has lots of rules.  Being run by a bank isnt all that much fun some times.  Many controls becasue we are a bank.

pros:
Stable Company
Decent compensation
Strong company Values
Many opportunities to advance if one is proactive.
cons: Work environment is counter to values of company. People regularly break company policy and federal laws, and middle management doesn't care, unless employees aren't matching sales goals. Upper management outlines goals, but due to pressure along the chain of command, these are not carried out on a day to day basis by many employees.

review_title: Community Banking is all about production
job_title: Personal Banker I in Baltimore, MD
pros: Opportunity to grow if sales is your strength.  Great Benefits and some really good managers. If you like customer service this is a great career for you.
cons: Too much focus on sales which does not  follow the " Do what is right for the customer" ideals.  Too much micro managing daily numbers which leads to a lot of turnover among Bankers .

pros: good to great pay with opportunities for bonuses on both sales and service. great benefits including medical, paid time off, holidays, and 401k matching. locations everywhere make it easy to transfer. if you do your job well, management will work hard to get you wherever you want to be in the company.
cons: there really aren't many cons. obviously sales is not for everyone, but that's not included in every job title. i wish the company was a little more energy/green efficient.

pros: plenty of support under the right manager
cons: inconsistent goals. You focus on one thing for a few days then ask why their isn't enough sales in another.

review_title: OK for a short period of time
pros: You can always get time off, they have a set hours no matter how slow business is. Pay is decent but only a dollar more than min wage. There is a little bit of bonus you can get every quarter.
cons: Managers get moved around so much. People are always doing whats better for their sales rather then the customer. Its hard to watch co workers force others into something that will not help them financially.

review_title: Overall a very fulfilling experience, with the ability to hone in on customer service and sales skills.
pros: Competitive benefits, never having to work late, lots of free programs and online learning modules to improve skills, all major holidays are off and paid
cons: Slow to be promoted, very scripted, not very flexible in hours, lots of regulations, managers are very much into micro-managing, incredibly high and often unreasonable sales goals

job_title: Financial Advisor Trainee in Cleveland, OH
pros: Diverse backgrounds of colleagues.  Strong management team.  Very good initial training.  Great resources/products.
cons: It's a very tough industry to get started from the ground.  Quite honestly I have all of the tools I need to be successful and I should be doing better than I am.  Any trainee getting started had better have a good network and one hell of a business plan.

review_title: Good growth in experience, and ample training tools.
job_title: Home Preservation Specialist I in Des Moines, IA
pros: Shows appreciation in a variety of ways. Gives plenty of notice so company compliance will not be a problem.
cons: Too many changes, going beyond flexability. My experience with a manager was horrible, and definitely needed better managerial skills.

job_title: Operations Clerk in New York, NY
pros: The best reasons to work here would be the excellent reputation that Wells Fargo has.
cons:
The cons of working here are the move towards managed money. There is a strong push with the new President of Wells Fargo Advisors which is creating a lot of resentment with "old-school" brokers. The investment banking services for clients also seem to be lacking for the size of the firm.
The firm is also very bureaucratic, it takes a long time to get anything done.

review_title: Good culture with a lot of help from the team. The review is for WBR
job_title: Analytics Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
+ Good work/life balance
+ Manager is understanding; team members can make recommendations to improve the process
+ Good teamwork
+ Training is appropriate for new team members. You can always ask your team members for help. Wells Fargo gives you time to study for necessary exams for your position.
+ Opportunity to move up
+ Company values team members
cons: + The compensation is not as high as the other big banks for the same position

review_title: Leaders were dishonest and did not value team members.  I worked in HR and witnessed lack of integrity.
job_title: Learning Consultant II in Charlotte, NC
pros: There were some great team members who worked hard.  The physical environment in Charotte, NC was comfortable and employee friendly.
cons: You could not trust the leaders to do the right thing.  Employees were not allowed to use their strengths and collaborate.

job_title: Assistant Branch Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Lots of room for growth with the right attitude and hours were good
cons: Culture stinks, you're introduced to this company of great ethics and strategies in place to help your customer succeed then in turn as soon as you hit the branch OTJ all you hear is SELL SELL SELL!

job_title: Licensed Personal Banker in Greenville, SC
pros: I enjoyed the people I worked with. Some aspects were fun. Benefits were strong, especially 401k and health insurance.
cons: This is more of a sales organization than a bank. The focus is on increasing sales, growing pipeline and marketshare. Many of the decisions that a traditional banker could have made personally are made off-site in a back office. Though the culture was focused on increasing sales, the salespeople were not adequately compensated for growth.

job_title: Finance Manager in San Francisco, CA
pros: Overall, Wells Fargo [NYSE:  WFC] is a well-run company with many opportunities for advancement.  I was employed by WFC for over nine years and was promoted several times during my tenure with the company.  WFC offers many training opportunities which I still find of value after leaving the company.
cons: In a few situations, it's the "Wells Fargo way" or the highway.  Not always flexible.

review_title: I love everything about my job, but a Lead Teller is the hardest position.
job_title: Lead Teller in San Diego, CA
pros: Wells Fargo focuses on excellent customer service and personal growth for each team member, which I love.
cons: Lead teller is one of the hardest positions. As a lead teller, you must be able to multitask. You have to keep up with the duties of a supervisor and paperwork as well as teller duties and daily sales goals.

review_title: Great Place to work and advance your career.
pros: I enjoyed the ability to work independently. I was able to set my goals and was given the tools to achieve them.
cons: I felt the companies heart was in the right place and do put the customer as #1 priority, but they did not become the largest mortgage company in the USA accidentally. They foresee market trends in advance and act on them aggressively, putting stress on work flows which lengthens processing time, in turn, makes it hard to manage customer expectations.

pros: Wells Fargo had historically promoted from within, but that appears to be changing.  The culture faces significant challenges when external hires perceive a necessity to ignore cultural norms and address the exigencies of the circumstance.
cons: See above - it's the balance that makes the company work, and in certain divisions and departments, that is threatened.

pros: Family oriented company, rewards for hard work and dedication, stable, and great benefits package
cons: May need to work past your scheduled time to leave, when systems change they do not consult with those who would actually use the new system for direction on its applicability, location (depending on where you live), hold insurance reps to the security standards of their bank.

job_title: Quality Assurance Analyst III in Lewisville, TX
pros: WF is an overall great company to work for! My department is a laid back atmosphere. Employees seems to work well together and great place if you are great with self management.
cons: Too many office politics, and favor amongst Upper Management with hiring of friends and family. Prepare to fight your way to the top if you are from a different demographic.

pros: Great hard-working employees who want to do a good job.  Flexibility to work from home depending on the group.
cons: Wells Fargo is not the company it once was.  Recognizing and rewarding employees is compulsory and dis-ingenuous.  Management is cold and distant.  Human Resources is protecting the company, not the employee.  Promotion of managers who are not equipped to lead and inspire people.

pros: Benefits are good overall. Great community involvement.
cons: With the rising cost of insurance and basic living expenses Wells Fargo's does not take that into consideration in determining salaries or raises. The moral of employees is not good, mostly due to the low salaries.

job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Orange, CA
pros: very flexible with work schedule if your manager likes you
cons: You will be managed depending how you look on a report and there are many reports that come out daily, its all about politics and how well your management team likes you.  The bonuses are really bad they have been the same for the last 10 years and it has become more dificult to hit the goals

pros: Wells Fargo has  great two week training program, great benefits after a short period of time, a good amount of paid time off, and bonus opportunities.
cons: The sales expectations at Wells Fargo are way too high. The lowest expectation that they have with no pay out, is opening around 1 checking/savings account every shift.

pros: Support team members with tools to do the job.  Support team members in community volunteer activities.  Support collaboration and teamwork.  Support recognition.
cons: bureaucratic procedures very dynamic due to attempting to be in compliance with consistent regulations.  Some service groups because they are centralized cannot support project timelines.

job_title: Phone Banker II in San Antonio, TX
pros: Can't really think of one other than you get to eat alot. Tons of pot luck for every occasion
cons: They dnt tell u but this job is all about sales. PB3 will be in your ear telling u to pitch a credit card to 85+ old customers. Every 10 minutes u get a status. If you like that apply. You might bonus but it's difficult, they make it almost impossible or find some way to take it away. Better off if your bilingual in spanish. Customer service is not even a factor..Wells Fargo lacks moral and ethical sales integrity. That's why they are the highest earning bank people

job_title: Research/Remediation Analyst II in Birmingham, AL
pros: Competitve pay makes working for Wells attractive. Generous time off is a plus. Teams are small, so you will usually know your teammates.
cons: Weak leadership. Management is a revolving door and employees find it difficult to bond with their team leaders. Managers run the gamut from intense micro-managers to very hands-off, with no consistency.

pros: Pros to working with Wells are the benefits: good amount of PTO, great wages, good insurance, and up to 6% match for 401k. Tenure here seems to be very long for most employees because there are so many opportunities to transfer and stay within the company.
cons: Interview and hiring process was very long. From the time I received notification for my first interview to my start date was about 3 months.

pros: Great benefits and a ton of training for this position. Made a lot of friends right away!
cons: Ugh...same thing day in-day out. And you're constantly monitored so if you screw up on the phone, your points drop. You get a chance to correct your mistakes but, oftentimes those 5 watched calls a month are terrifying haha.

pros: Fast growth and movement in company if you are driven to sale day and night.  Mostly enjoyed my clients and training new staff members
cons: very competitive and sales driven. As management spent a lot of time on the phone with HR due to WF upper management being strict on sales goals of employees

pros: The hours worked well so I could finish my bachelor's degree. Plus, for being in college, I made a decent amount of money.
cons: They were very pushy for sales. A few times would require us to stay late or work on my Saturday off to make cold calls.

review_title: If you're competitive in achieving high numbers, this is your fit
pros: You will reach 40 hours every week and in that time you will get to know the community and the people around you.
cons: You will be working for a massive bank, which means there will be pressure from the ranks above for you to meet store and personal goals. You will be assessing each and every customer to try and match them to a product that you think will benefit them and they will make sure you do just that.

review_title: Wonderful Company to work for if you are at this branch
job_title: Personal Banker- Business Advocate in Haltom City, TX
pros: The manager here is the best of the best, she is very understanding and helpful to your every need. Working here with the employees and customers that come into the branch was wonderful. They are very loving and down to earth. Company alone loves their employees and often have events for them to show their appreciation.
cons: If you do not meet your sales goals than you do not get your extra pay out at the end of the quarter.

job_title: Teller At Wells Fargo in San Angelo, TX
pros: Benefits - Sales Training - Pay, somewhat - Vacation Leave Available - Holidays Off
cons: High turnover rate, aggressive selling standards, short staffed and the standards that were set for selling were not being fully executed by all of our managers in the two stores which I worked. Tellers & managers planning vacations with each other, completely unprofessional. Jokes, Harassment, Favoritism, Attendance issues overlooked and certain people held accountable while others were not.

job_title: Teller At Wells Fargo in Larchmont Village, CA
pros: Steady job , 9-6 hrs , good benefits
cons: Horrible Management, a lot of favoritism, too much stress & pressure on sales for not enough pay . If you like being robotic at a job then this is the one for you .

pros: Great relationships with bankers and clients. Great 401k.  As long as you're good at your job, it's very secure.
cons: Current sales environment and negative publicity have made sales success difficult.  Value as an employee is questionable.  Little opportunity to advance within current position.

pros: Great company culture at Wells Fargo. They really care about their employees and take good care of them. Good work/life balance. Overall good morale, they really motivate you to hit your quarterly goals and move up in the company.
cons: Can be a bit micro-managed at times. Some branches have high turnover with tellers causing you to pick up more hours. Work on Saturdays. Sales are sometimes too emphasized.

review_title: It's not hard work. As a lead you supervise tellers coach around their weaknesses and reinforce their strengths.
pros: Nice hours. Good benefits, tons of paid time off holidays off. Alright medical plan. Locations all over Austin, school assistance is also offered. Benefits are available for part time employees as well.
cons: Not much room to move up, at least in Austin retail. Management is not well prepared on the retail side. Negative publicity has affected morale as well.

review_title: Other companies value their employees more
job_title: Service MANAGER I in Columbia, MD
pros: Overall good company and benefits, they train employees for extensively. Promotional opportunities or slim. Many locations across the US makes it a little easier to transfer if you've  been your position a year.
cons: Under paid. It almost benefits to be and external hire rather that be promoted within the company as the will offer you to lowest pay rate. Favoritism is very real with the "who you know " rather than the "what you know"

review_title: Hated the sales goals, but they eliminated sales and now customer service based
pros: The benefits are great, the pay I think is fair, corporate has been really appreciating the employees lately with goodies after all the bad publicity last year
cons: Constantly being observed by management for improvement. They will observe an entire session with customers and go over everything we need improvement on. Also want us to call every single customer we help the following day, 2 weeks out, and 2 months out. Overkill and annoying to customers

job_title: Credit Portfolio Consultant in Sioux Falls, SD
pros: Good people here with strong work ethic and still balance on life. Opportunities to grow your skills if you're willing to put in the effort
cons: Recognition and pay scale specific to this area could be better.

review_title: Low income but Steady whether you work or not
job_title: Processor, Underwriter in Fort Mill, SC
pros: Benefits were the only perk
cons: The location in Fort Mill SC shows favoritism in cliche's, only a $1/hour raise in 3 years, always top producer but never rewarded or promoted. All management does is Delegate and wants the best producers on floor rather than promote. Also doesn't help to be publicly asked questions of the integrity of the company when I worked there.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Yakima, WA
pros: Good lead system.  Great coworkers.  Can be rewarding.  You make your own schedule.  Great product and program options that fit almost any/every need.
cons: Lack of ownership; everybody passes the buck on most issues.  Is usually a lengthier process than most regional competitors. Time management isn't the best; feels like a lot of time wasted on multiple meetings covering the same issues.

review_title: Good Organization; left looking for Career Change
pros: Having been at Wells for 13 years, I was in a nice working group. I did have the opportunity to work in different areas in the bank.
cons: There was a limit on ability to learn new technologies. Recent changes in senior management have diminished the ownership that individual teams used to feel.

pros: Diversity , volunteer work , awesome pay , rewards and recognition , employee referral policies  (Politics will be everywhere , so be positive and move on)..
cons: More importance to stateside teams and team members in all.(70 percent new initiatives will be assigned to stateside)

job_title: CONSUMER LOAN UNDERWRITER in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Although there has been negative press regarding the company lately, which only represents a few of the employees, this is a very good place to work.  the majority are ethical, company wants what is best for both the employees and customers.  benefits are great, and the company provides stable employment.
cons: more telecommuting options for positions where could be done, sometimes production goals are not realistic, exceptional workers should receive more pay and reviewed.

job_title: Personal Banker in San Francisco, CA
pros: Diversity initiatives through community groups, Educational component into financial industry when hired as a banker
cons: Terrible culture driven by number of checking accounts per day vs doing what is right for the client. Asked to open accounts and transfer funds from existing accounts to push multiple accounts. Branches are held to number of checking account goals.

job_title: Home Loan Processor in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The benefits and paid time off are awesome. The culture and atmosphere is very supportive and motivating. The grounds are also kept very clean. I never wake up dreading going to work.
cons: Hard to promote/get in with another position. Seems only jobs available are either very low pay (ie a starter job) or very high paying job (meant for someone with loads of experience and a bachelors degree at least). There really is nothing available in the middle.

review_title: Unusual lack of civility and support from senior management
pros: Proud to have partnered with good friends and colleagues who deliver on a daily basis  to unrealistic deadlines and with little support from their management.
cons: A cultural change is desperately needed in the one division I experienced. Managers are unable to articulate objectives or requirements, and resort to public verbal abuse of staff to vent their frustration

pros: knowledge service was good, a lot of learning opportunity nice office. But it was important to get into the right team in here
cons: The culture has been getting ruined because of the new senior management hired, because they bring along with them the bad culture and experience of their previous organization

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in New York, NY
pros: Compensation, benefits, exposure to a high volume of clients. Good place to learn the nuts and bolts of banking and high level corporate finance.
cons: Little or no M&A executed by this firm. Investment bank is just a check in the box for Wells Fargo and a small part of the overall revenue. Therefore, there is a lack of focus and clear strategy on winning M&A mandates.  Without M&A experience it is near impossible to break into solid buy side roles.

job_title: Front Desk Agent in Winder, GA
pros: studied to be an executive secretary. It is time to do what I learned. I am sure that the best place to do so is to work in a bank.
cons: the changes are going to be many but I like the challenges I'm ready to take them

review_title: Wells Fargo has changed but not for the better
pros: There is an abundance of work to be done, solving and fixing big problems that exist throughout the bank. Most of the hardworking team members are very good people.
cons: You will likely spend most of your days frustrated because leadership doesn’t want real change they measure success by activities not outcomes. This is a highly politicized environment.

job_title: Loan Servicing Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: Some of your co workers are great. The retention in BBG side was good. Insurance was good.
cons: Insurance fee steadily increases every year but nothing more is offered in return. It's never about what you know but who you know when applying for different departments. There was no training at all for my position. The team lead wad horrendous! Every single person in the department had filed multiple complaints, HR "investigated " incidents but still nothing wad done and she maintained her role with no consequence. Pay is horrible.

review_title: Work for Wells Fargo, you might want to think about it!
pros: Wells Fargo gives their employees alot of training to make them the best of the best. They also provide a great benefits program.
cons: Upper management always claim that family is important, however when it comes down to it Wells Fargo has to come first.

pros:
Talented and professional peers
Balance sheet likely to lead to greater market share when recovery begins
cons:
Legacy-Wachovia management appears to have little influence over business decisions
Difficult economic climate and lack of transparency on potential compensation leading to poor office morale
Wells Fargo still struggling with integration of investment and corporate bank
"External hire" culture with few success stories of advancment from Associate/VP to MD

job_title: Personal Banker I in Redding, CA
pros:
Great benefit
Ability to promote
4 week paid vacation first day on the job
Ability to make bonus each quarter
cons:
Less pay than competitors
The customer comes after the product
Sell as much crap as you can
Each branch differs by region

pros: It is a very big company, stable job, great health and retirement benefits along with reasonable time off for beginning employees.
cons: poor hours, no opportunity for growth within financial, very low pay respectively, high level of secrecy between managemtent and their employees.

pros: Great benefits, easy to get time off when needed. Pay is in line with the competition, and quarterly bonuses can be substantial if goals are met.
cons: Constantly getting hounded and micromanaged if you are not hitting your goals. More about sales than providing customer service. Job security is always on your mind when trying to achieve set sales goals.

pros: Good work/life balance, excellent opportunities to create your own career path and move into different parts/business units in the enterprise, sound, strong company on the Street
cons: Some managers only seek favor to those they brought into the organization and treat any others with complete disrespect.  Other higher/SVP hiring decisions from the outside are a complete disaster - they don't know and can't embrace the Vision and Values of the company.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Steady income, customer base is good.
cons: Long time employee and recognition is gone. As a top performer (top 10% of the entire company)  they are not willing to do anything to retain employees who are doing well, especially when you're "just a banker". Can't get the time off requested. No increases when you're just above midrange, even if you perform at a level 5 rating. (it's been too long since an increase)

pros:
- Good benefits package (Great is you  have a family to insure)
- Looks good on a resume
- Flexible hours
cons:
-Tolerate bad management
- Excessive pressure to sale and no feedback or praise when doing well
- Dictatorship rather than a team led store

pros: Bonuses, Team atmosphere, and overall processes make it an OK place to work.
cons:
Solutions goals are consistently increasing, without having new products rolling out. 
Customer service scoring system is not fair to Team Members. 
Management only promotes Full-time employees.

review_title: A challenging journey I am glad I got to take.
pros: Lots of PTO time.  Great benefits.  Matching 6% of 401K.  Lots of opportunites to learn and develop new skills.
cons: Sometimes you will feel left out of something if you are not in the right click.  Reminds you of high school only we are all supposed to be adults.

review_title: LOTS of entry level positions available for those who need a job change.
pros: LOTS of entry level positions available for those who need a job change.  Company, in general, is gay friendly.  Company allows team members to volunteer and pays them to do so.
cons: Management is hand held most of the time; too afraid to make decisions without getting prior approval from Senior Management.

review_title: Annoying, very lame atmosphere where everyone, even management, is treated like a child by their superiors.
pros:
Tellers get paid more than other banks.
Been there a year and get over three weeks paid vacation a year.
Not the worst way to begin a sales career if you have no college degree.
cons:
Besides teller every other position is paid poorly compared to other banks.
Corporate atmosphere is lame and annoying.
Goals go up, while compensation goes down yearly.
Constant customer complaints due to inferior interest rates, high fees, and low customer benefits.
Internet access has been takes away for all tellers.

pros: Easy job that paid really well. hours were fairly flexible. the people that worked there were professional. the home mortgage campus was nice.
cons: the corporate stuff is borderline ridiculous. I dealt with it by telling myself  my inflated pay was to deal with all of their corporate garbage. that was really the only bad thing about it.

pros: There are only 2 pro's for this job. I like the people that work with me in the branch and it's an easy inside job
cons:
1- No opportunity to move up, all they want to hire is part time and it's hard as junk to get anything else
2- they expect ridiculous sales goals, but make it extremely hard to reach those goals
3- upper management doesn't give a crap about it's employees

review_title: Nice place to visit, wouldn't want to work there
pros: Career opportunities and promotions are available to most who work hard and are willing to relocate to other states or cities.
cons: Management solely focuses on the numbers rather than the employees.  Which discourages employees to give 100%.  Since no one acknowledges your efforts why go to great lengths to achieve more.

job_title: Client Service Consultant II in Menomonee Falls, WI
pros: PTO, free lunch, good work/life balance
cons: office politics, management, compensation, company says they care about your advancement with the "IDP" process but limit ability to apply for other positions if your team is short staffed or you haven't met a 1 year requirement in your current role. the company is big on your brand and if you say one wrong thing your brand is ruined.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Shoreview, MN
pros: The management is great, the people who work with you are fun.
cons: Difficult to get PTO approved. Very micro-managed.

review_title: Very pleasurable company to work for
pros: They offer excellent benefits and take care of you.  It is a very secure company and there is always opportunity to move up at Wells.
cons: Because it is such a large bank it can sometimes feel as if you're lost in the company.  There is a lot of variation in management styles throughout the organization...I guess just like any other large company.

pros: pay is competitive, and its easy to move up fast
cons: no matter the market area, all employees are expected to obtain the same sales goals, which in rural areas, are unattainable. This company only cares about meeting sales numbers, and will fire anyone who does not. As a former manager, I know this for fact. Poor upper management and unreachable goals make this a horrible company to work for.

job_title: Application Systems Engineer in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Wells Fargo has a good history of taking excellent care of its employees.  This includes compensation, benefits and time off.  They offer excellent job stability and offer many training and promotion opportunities.
cons: The introduction of Wachovia corporate culture is diminishing employee moral.  Insurance, time off, and compensation all took a hit after the merger.  Some of the value of being employed at Wells Fargo has consequently diminished.

review_title: It's a great company to start a career with if you're not sure what you want to get into.
job_title: Bank Teller in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: There are a lot of benefits, like tution reimbursement, and discounts on cell phone service and insurance.
cons: If you're not a 9-5 (sometimes 6 or 7), this job is not for you. Also, if being in an office isn't you ideal job location, a bank is probably not where you should go.

review_title: Great work environment, vital position in the company
pros: Goal oriented, results driven, customer focused.  Always striving to provide a banking experience like no other while offering financial services catered to the customers needs. Offered awesome military incentives
cons: Not always using the most efficient business practices.  Too much access to secure areas and resources given to employees.  Mandatory "sales pitches" incorporated into every customer interaction.

Benefits

If a cust calls in wanting their balance, we have to try to get them to sign up for a credit card. The referral/sales goals are very aggressive. It's annoying. Try to get into another dept that's not working on the phones.

Health/dental benefits

Toxic environment
Terrible management
No direction

review_title: The management was forceful into shoving products down clients throats.

Being in a smaller town, people came in and didn't need to be hassled every time they came in.  It caused many customers to seek other financial institutions that didn't push so much.
