I understand the nature of a merger/acquisition and the fallout that it brings. However, when you are working heads down in the trenches, you expect honesty from those at the helm.

pros: Wells Fargo as a company is pretty good to have on your resume and you could get other jobs pretty easily because Wells is known for its sales focused reputation. I have made a handful of friends as well and people are generally nice.
cons: In my experience Wells cares more about the number than the customer. Many many instances where you can call bankers on poor ethics but is ok'd by the store manager to get numbers. Very sales intensive over everything and you have to follow a cheesy script every transaction and it just seems so fake and customers do take notice.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Lynnwood, WA
pros: Food training, benefits,  and vacation. Several opportunities for advancement. All in all a good place to work but each branch offers a different atmosphere
cons: It takes 1 year minimum with any position you start with to advance. your goal is to move widgets ultimately pushing products onto your clients, cc's insurance, mortgage... whether it is a need of theirs or not.  Management will flat out lie to you about promotions in order to obtain proutine.  In my experience not the most ethical company.

pros: Great corporate culture.  Very generous matching, 6% matching 401K.  A generous amount of PTO.  Co-workers are very smart.  Great recognition for hard work.
cons: I have had some opportunity to work on different projects but for the most part my job can feel like  a silo.   There is a lot of lengthy corporate procedures that make getting help difficult. There are also some HR hoops to jump through from time to time.

pros: Offer overtime if you need it. PTO. Bonus. I guess there is a 20 word minimum. So. Call center environment. Is pretty nice. Could be a lot worse!
cons: They sometimes required 17 hrs overtime monthly. PTO is accrued monthly so if u want a 3 day vacation. Don't take off for any reason for at least 2 months before. Bonuses are next to impossible to reach with all their requirements. Hours long. Customers are angry. Modifications are a joke. Except to work on Sunday.

review_title: Lacks on boarding process but supports virtual workforce
job_title: Technology Manager III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I like the potential opportunities and the fact the company is financially sound. They have right sized as they have made acquisitions and have a long tenured workforce.
cons: Large, virtual workforce. Constantly on the phone versus in person interactions. Some of the facilities are large and outdated.

job_title: Retirement Service Representative in Roseville, MN
pros: The management is easy to work with and the ability to move yourself up is there if you like the path that is laid out.
cons: The size and speed of a company this size is crippling sometimes, there not a lot of urgency for tech development which makes doing your job more difficult.

review_title: Most Aweful job in the History of Aweful jobs
pros: 3 weeks a year vacation/sick time.  And hey you get breaks...
cons: If you like getting yelled at ALL day long, like having your calls monitored for PERFECTION, and can tinkle in under 2 minutes, this is the job for you.  If not, there are less stressful jobs out there.

pros: Competitive pay, decent compensation for sales, 401k with a 6% match after first year. Great benefits as well as discounts with every day stuff such as phone bills car buying discounts etc...
cons: Like every other review the sales are steep but if you truly do what you're supposed to and don't mind working the phone as well as lobby then you should be fine and meet them with putting in a decent amount of effort

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Carmel-by-the-Sea, CA
pros: Worked at Wells for 5 years.  They have a huge customer base. They are into frequent training.  At least they feed you well at these events.
cons: Extremely slow processing and fulfillment. Couldn't care less about the individual employee or customer.  They just have another warm bodied employee or customer lined up to ride the stagecoach.

review_title: Pleasure to work again and again
pros: Destination for finance guys. Great company to work. excellent infrastructure. Leading Bank in the World (Holds 30 Rank in Fortune 500 Companies)
cons: HRBP & Higher Management should focus more in finding reasons for attrition's and come up with a strong action plan for managers. One major reason is lack of managements skills which leads to dissatisfaction of employees.

job_title: Inside Sales Specialist in Breinigsville, PA
pros: It was hard to meet the quota's that were needed to meet the metrics for bonus payout.  I should have stayed in consumer sales, where I was getting 2200 to 3100 dollar quarterly bonuses.
cons: They told me that I was oin the fast track and pulled me over to premier within 6 mos and it took all my bonuses away because my product that people wanted dropped away, all I sold were Home Equities.  These wealthier clients already had all the accounts they needed.

pros: Decent pay and good benefits. Lots of vacation days and many paid holidays. This is a good place to start and move up because they are a huge company, so there are so many opportunities.
cons: A lot of pressure to make sales goals, and your goals increase every year. They expect more and more even if you do great, and then they still want more.

job_title: Financial Analyst in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good understanding of how banks make commercial real estate loans. All types of loans for all types of assets. Management is strong and is the best at what they do
cons: Very conservative, will lose a lot of deals to more aggressive banks on terms and pricing. A lot of the analyst work is compliance. The new relationship managers will work on the underwriting of most of the deals because they want to prove themselves. DIfficult to work on new deals in that circumstance.

job_title: Inbound Sales Specialist in Richmond, VA
pros: The money isn't too bad, just like any job, it has its ups and downs.
cons: Used to think the bank actually cared about its customers, not so much anymore....as a sales rep, they just force you to shove products down customers throats. The referrals from customer service are horrible and upper management refuses to look into the problem. They need to hire people that actually care about thier jobs...not just some hood rat off the street because they have a nice voice

pros: It's a good place to get your foot in the door for banking. There are a lot of different career avenues to pursue with this company. Benefits are pretty solid.
cons: The micromanagement can mind numbing at times. The company likes the idea of great customer service but their reality is far from it. You will have to force banking products on any and everybody whether they need them or not.

pros: The sales training one receives with the company is some of the best I have seen. If you are willing to work hard you can make a lot of money in comissions. Management team is supportive and helpful with all problems
cons: Pressure can sometimes be too high with sales goals. Being as I am commissioned I have to "pay back" any pto so it's not actually company paid time.

review_title: Care Very little for their employees
pros: Wells Fargo has some awesome benefits and some decent pay. overall if you are just looking for a place to get paid this would be ok.
cons: Biggest downside at least for the department I am in is the extreme lack of care for the employees. One quote was "we want you here more than with your families." Forced overtime, lack of communication, complete lack of flexibility to work with you and your schedule. management is always changing what they want to do.

pros: I like the place. People are usually pretty friendly to me. Sometimes I do get into fights with some of them. - especially at the bar.
cons: Sometimes the place sucks. The people here are a bunch of punks sometimes. Other times you can have a very good day. The major con is the hours of bordom

pros: There are numerous opportunities for advancement with in the company. Or, one can embark on delving into new areas of business or a different department to enchance job growth and advancement. This company promotes hiring from with in. The work/life balance is excellent. The benefits are stellar.
cons: Advancement is limited in certain departments, due to the needs of the business, which is common for the industry. Salaries must be negotiated well upon hire as yearly raises are minimal.

pros: The environment is fun, need more employee/manager interaction in order to build the morale of employees.  Dealer services can great start to a career with Wells Fargo.
cons: Working nights and weekends, opportunities are minimum, the more you know the harder it is for you to become a candidate in other areas in the office.

pros: Wells has an excellent training program that follows the same format as the other bulge brackets. Depending on how you feel about location, training is in Charlotte - a pro or con if you're from a big city.
cons: The company is massive and IB is HQ in Charlotte. It can be difficult to seem relevant when you're in another office.

job_title: Part Time Teller in Sacramento, CA
pros: good company culture, great team members, if you like people, this is a great interactive job. a lot of resources provided by the company
cons: if sales isn't your thing, this isn't the job for you. though wells fargo has placed more emphasis on a customer care culture instead of sales, you still have to meet your goals. pressure may be tough

pros: I worked for the main branch in Corona and it was a great experience overall . I had a great service manager who was fully supportive and the teller staff was great. Working with the bankers and as a team was a lot of fun and a challenge at some points in the job.
cons: The pay could have been better and I did not like the pressure of selling with Wells. It's nice to have customers that want to see you without having to hassle them for sales

review_title: Great place to work while in school
pros: Tuition reimbursement program is very helpful, huge organization with plenty of opportunity to move around and find a job that best fits you and your skill set.
cons: A large corporation and feels like one. At times it is easy to get lost in the shuffle, or feel like your voice isn't being heard.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Union City, NJ
pros:
Benefits
Salary
PTO
you will work within 30 minutes of your home.
team members treat you like family and are very nice
cons: management only care about them. unrealistic sales goals. if you don't lie or do unethical things you will never reach your goal, and even if you do, they will as for more

pros:
-great co-workers
-promote from inside
-support the community with toy-drives, food donations, adopt a family
-hourly for tellers is now $11+ and 13+ for lead tellers
-as of October 2016 no sales quotas
-friendly and respectful management. also supportive in career choice, medical, accommodations such as injury or specific needs
cons:
-because of the lawsuits, nobody knows what sort of quota will be made for year 2017
-long hours, sometimes 9-10hr shifts with only one break.

job_title: Digital Strategy Consultant in San Francisco, CA
pros: The innovation group has a great working environment and a wonderful management team. There is a lot of opportunity for advancement.
cons: I can't think of any downsides unless you don't like actually doing work. There are definitely high expectations so if you get into this department you should be passionate about what you do.

pros: Benefits are better than most jobs out there. Paid time off is very good.
cons: Pay raises are terrible! 25 cents average. Not happy with want the company has done for the new pay increase for the newbies to bring them up to what I am making, I've been with WF for just over 15 years!!! Its BS. Honor those that are better than average employees with better pay. Don't give a raise to those that don't deserve it. It should be earned!!!

pros: Wells Fargo offers great benefits even for part timers. You get an awesome amount of paid time off. Small annual raises but atleast it's something. They also are very big on hiring internally.
cons: They don't hire full time. The sales have been a little aggressive in the past and that is the biggest con, worrying that it could come back.

job_title: Project Manager IV in Charlotte, NC
pros:
I have felt like the company and all my managers really care about me and my family (hard to come by with large companies). 
Great flexibility with my schedule and office location. I now work from home. 
Great pay and benefits. 
Currently a 6% 401k match. 
Many great opportunities to move up the ladder or to move into another field.
cons: With large companies there is a lot of red tape to get through which can make changes to policy and applications slow.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Charlotte, NC
pros: Potential to make money.
cons: Since the media scandal, the reputation has affected our chances of making money. Management only seems to care about the top money making HMC. The bilingual teams are not as appreciated. English calls are not routed to us anymore. They want us to now call customers on a daily basis for 4 hours or more a day to beg for business, which is a way to gain back their reputation.

pros: Great place to settle.Good salary, employee friendly organisation. Not much work. Good work and personal life balance. Very good for women.
cons: Not a good place for learning, technology wise very bad. If you want to learn and grow in the industry not a good place. Turning to be service based company from capitave mode. Few key people from service based company spoiling the company culture.

review_title: Business analyst for the Private Client Group serving as an internal consultant for one arm of our brokerage channel.
job_title: Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Wells Fargo Advisors is a great place to work because it has great Employee benefits, a collaborative work environment, and strong team member network.
cons: The politics that exist in any large corporation like Wells Fargo make it difficult to make decisions in a timely manner to meet deadlines.

review_title: Relationship Mgr. Business Banking Group Vice President
pros: It's a stable company to work for. As any large company, they have solid benefits: 401k, insurance, free bank account, etc.  They don't bother your process as long as you perform. Low stress.
cons: It's a good ole boy system in TX.  Same rules dont apply to everyone, cronyism.  Definitely a glass ceiling if you dont appear to fit the mold. Local management loves President Trump.  If they feel you're outside of this, don't plan to be promoted.

review_title: Aggressive Sales Tactics Encouraged, Ethics Checked At The Door
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Great health benefits, 401K plan that was matched, paid time off, opportunities to earn quarterly bonuses if sales goals are met.
cons: Required sales goals were simply unobtainable. The merger with Wachovia also brought a mandatory script with all customers, including those that have been using the same branch for several years,  that was robotic and came off as disingenuous.

review_title: Premier banker formerly Regional Bank Private banker
pros: great benefits including vacation, sick pay, paid volunteer time, 401k match up to 6%
cons: diminished recognition programs, lower bonus incentive, unclear on newer promotion criteria, bad press due to recent settlements which also cause reduced patronage, too much competition in branch setting with multiple licensed bankers in every store, limited calling on prospects

pros: Benefits, teamwork focused, room for growth. Coaching on your career path specific to your strengths. Nationwide opportunities. Various lines of business allowing for more than just retail banking.
cons: The only real con I can think of would be having to work on weekends. It used to be having to work until 6 PM or so but many of the branches have shortened their hours.

review_title: Be wary of "promotions" from non-exempt to exempt
job_title: Applications SYSTEMS ENGINEER in Charlotte, NC
pros:
Generous paid time off (PTO)
Good health care benefits
They match contributions of up to 6% of your salary to your 401K
Flexible schedule
Work at home opportunity, although this appears to be coming to an end
cons:
Promotion to exempt position may result in less overall pay when factoring loss of overtime pay.
Training options can be limited due to lack of travel dollars and unwillingness to allow employees to attend conferences, regardless of relevance.
Work at home option subject to revocation without consideration of performance.

job_title: Investment Banking Analyst in Charlotte, NC
pros: Analyst IB roles anywhere are tough, but WFS is about as good as it gets from a work/life balance perspective.  Deal flow is decent and the majority of the people you work with are great.  Pretty low jerk contingent (relatively speaking).  Fantastic office (Duke Energy Center).
cons: Some of the people there are complete fools, but I've heard that has been changing with recent layoffs (about time).  Was there for scandal - impacted IB business a little bit, but not bad.

job_title: Home Preservation in West Des Moines, IA
pros: Good people too work with, great benefits, loved the amenities at the WDM campus. Loved doing one-on-ones with management. Award ceremonies were cool too if your competitive. Management was very good at keeping you up to date on how you were doing and how to improve. Was made aware of career growth within the company.
cons: Took away bonuses. If you’re really good at your job, you will have to pick up others slack.

review_title: Leadership is trial by fire; don't plan, just execute, if you screw it up, just adjust later
pros:
Benefits for Employees 
Client Focus for all team-members
Support for learning / development for team-members 
Client Reach / Market Penetration 
High Profile Shareholders 
Well Capitalized
cons:
Culture is "need to know", don't ask questions,  don't make suggestions,  salute and do what you are told;  company can make money this way  but it won't create long-term loyal team-members 

Many departments seem to have high turnover;

review_title: good place to work if you like your position
pros: Everyone seems to be nice and has a genuine concern for your well being. There are however the two faced people. But I guess that's everywhere.
cons: I just don't feel appreciated enough. I have worked 2 different positions with this company. The first one I absolutely ADORED!!!! The second however is blah..

pros:
Nice people
A good resume builder
Excellent FA training and support
Senior Leaders try to take care of their people
cons:
Part of a massive corporation so you have little impact on anything
Brokerage has lost independence and ability to make decisions
Feels like a bank not a brokerage
Compensation is dropping for the home office
Huge cultural rift still exists between legacy companies
Senior Leaders bound by red tape 
CEO has lost most of his power to run his own shop

review_title: Amount of volume and organization of process needs to be improved.
pros: It is a great place to learn to grow professionally and as a person.  Pay and benefits is great.  Staff is friendly.
cons:
Be prepared to do more work than you can handle.
Be prepared to deal with angry customers.
Be prepared to handle computer work, phone, email, voicemail, fax and extreme multitask.
Training was useless.

review_title: Too conservative and way behind the times in the online space, not a marketing company, a sales company.
job_title: Vice President, EBusiness in San Francisco, CA
pros: It is a very comfortable organization but it has very low expectations of employees because it takes years to do anything versus weeks or months.  Many current employees have been there for years and are very conservative or haven't progressed with the times.  Good thing they make money fist over fist or they would be very uncompetitive.
cons: slow, risk averse, not technology oriented, consumer experience rarely comes first

pros: Wells Fargo offers their employees great benefits, and are ususallt very understanding when you need to go to the doctor
cons: If you are not apart of the management team your voice in never heard it is like working for a sweat shop.  You are not compinsated for a job well done

pros: The opportunities on the retail banking side are there.  I went from a teller to a banker in under a year.
cons: Management is constantly breathing down your back.  I came from Wachovia, and now I'm starting to see a push to get the legacy Wachovia employees out.  It is a sales driven job, but employees who are tenured and make the numbers should be allowed to perform their own way.

pros: Great opportunity for growth and advancement, especially if you're willing to relocate to a larger city within the US.
cons:
Goals are always waaaaaaaaaaaaay above what's attainable, and go up 10% each year.  If you reach the goal, it wasnt set high enough for you.  

Long hours, little care about life outside of work, no time adjust days for working 9 hours on Saturdays.

review_title: highly political atmosphere, where potential opportunities abound if willing to sacrifice integrity
pros: Size/scale and associated opportunities to explore career options internally, external reputation
cons: there's a high value placed on consensus building which often masks the intrinsic inefficiency associated with a bloated leadership structure

review_title: A very supportive company to work for.
job_title: Documentation Specialist in San Antonio, TX
pros: They have a very diverse culture, encourage professional development, sponsor mentoring and growth, and have excellent benefits packages. Also, management works hard to make employees happy through employee recognition programs.
cons: This depends on the department you work for. Some are very dynamic and fair, others like using good old boy system.

review_title: Great place to start a career in Financial Services
pros: A great deal of support for young bankers out of college or university.  A great place to get licensed for investment production.
cons: Very low salary and bonus potential.  Not only that, but extremely hard to meet bonus requirements.  Business model does not seem sustainable.  Focus on quantity not quality, and not much opportunity for advancement.

review_title: Too big but lots opportunities if u know the right people
pros: Joined few years before the big merger and experienced the big diff pre and post merger. It's too big with lots of lines of bus to move around and learn. Good balance of work and life compare with typical wall street peers
cons: Too political, too budget concious and you really need to know the right ppl to advance

review_title: Good experience that can certainly be enhanced
pros: Big company with different possibilities to move within the organization. Oportunity to move within States and still work for the same company keeping one seniority.
cons: Being a big company has translated into certain areas / departments not being appreciated as much as they should.  Benefits, although still decent, used to be better.

job_title: Personal Banker I in Palmdale, CA
pros: Lots of opportunities for growth. Helpful management. Excellent training program. Company cares about its employees.
cons: HEAVY emphasis on sales. To the point of being a bit ridiculous. Things like opening three different checking savings account packages for one customer so that you can hit your numbers. The pressure to convince them that they need those things just so you can hit your numbers is enormous.

review_title: Overall, Wells Fargo is a great company!
pros: Salary and benefits are decent, and I am able to cover my domestic partner as well!
cons: Training was much longer than I feel was necessary and the systems are not exactly "user friendly", but changes are being made, though slowly.  I just have to remember that it's a very large company--things don't happen quickly with large companies!

pros: The starting pay was 13.50 which in my opinion is really good for a first time teller position. Great benefits such as 28% off AT&T bill.
cons: I worked in a district with horrible upper management. I heard bad things before I even meet the district manager... Not a good sign! Continuous micro-managing made it difficult to perform everyday tasks. Consist nagging about making unrealistic referrals goal that most people accomplish by "cheating".

review_title: I worked at Wells Fargo for 5 years! Wonderful benefits, average pay, ok place to work
job_title: Loan Adjuster Specialist in Milwaukee, WI
pros: Lots of opportunity, work atmosphere is comfortable.
cons: Particular division was over saturated with unprofessional management. I don't blame Wells Fargo company. People in that division just made bad choices.

pros: Within my last departement I was treated very well. My managers were unique in the way our group was handled. Good overall benefits.
cons: Management is too political. I had an idea my layoff was coming but I couldn't break into another group. The managers hired their old favorites and despite my qualifications would not even respond to me after I interviewed for new positions.After 22 years I was let go.

review_title: I care about my image - not your career
pros: Some really good people.  Stable company.  They try to build a good environment.  Good bennys.
cons: Nasty politics a permitted.  Image is more important than doing the right thing.  Most leaders care more for their careers than taking care of their team members.

review_title: Wells Fargo, Family Feel Internally, Supreme Service Externally
job_title: Home Preservation Specialist in Tempe, AZ
pros: Wells really cares about their employees. Management staff can relate to, and assist frontline workers because of 90% promotion from within. That being said, there is an excellent opportunity for advancement, career exploration at Wells.
cons: Up to date information is not always readily available for associates.  The intranet database is very confusing to use and doesn't always have the info or policy needed to assist with each situation.

job_title: Business Banking Specialist in San Francisco, CA
pros: Decent pay for the required work
cons: unorganized sales strategy, goals are continuously changing which basically makes it difficult to make your comp. Places you in a position to where it becomes a Catch 22 situation; if you don't hit your min sales, you get scrutinized, if you go above and beyond your sales goals, questions are raised and mgmt become suspicious you are gaming the system.

review_title: Fairly decent company to work for - probably on par with competitors.
pros: Friendly people to work with. Industry leading reputation. Decent support network from managers when needed. Most managers (DM's and above) have positive attitudes about work and production. Wells actively promotes from within - lots of opportunities.
cons:
Incentive goals are set above what most bankers achieve. Incentive pay schedule is poor. Cost of living pay increases are non existent, let alone a real raise. Managers micro manage.
Some managers don't know how to manage (don't have management skills)

review_title: It paid well, but not well enough to overcome the constant push for sales.
job_title: Bank Teller in College Station, TX
pros: It is decent pay as a part-time position. Hours and working days are great. Holidays off (but not paid). Looks great on a resume if you can hang in there. Coworkers are typically competent and great folks.
cons: There's not a ton of opportunities unless you plan to be a banker or bank manager forever -aka not a diverse set of job opportunities. The rules are strict, reasonably so, but the practice is not.

review_title: Zero autonomy and expect to be micromanaged regardless of performance
pros: Salary, training, resources, opportunity to move up the retail chain but not much outside of that. The people who also "get it" are great, but there's a lot who drink the kool-aid.
cons: About everything else other than salary and some cool people. In retail, it's one big game and sales ethics are thrown out the window, your quota rises every quarter while your bonus drops, "gaming" is common which is terrible.

review_title: Terrible place to work in the retail bank setting
job_title: Personal Banker II – Registered in Warminster Village, PA
pros: Decent 401k plan, ability to work almost anywhere in the United States. Stock price seems to always be on the rise.  Alot of opportunites in Investments and  home mortgage.
cons: Rediculous sales goals in the retail bank. No sales ethics what so ever. They dont care about customers or employees.  Constant turnover.  Incompetent worthless management.  Hourly micromanagement. Terrible commission structure.

job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Vancouver, WA
pros: Management, supervisors and staff are all positive and supportive. Great benefits for health, time off, educational assistance. Regular automatic salary adjustments based on your performance.  Good training and mentoring if you look to make WF your career
cons: The hours can be challenging depending on the department.  Performance standards are high but administered fairly.  Banking involves lots of changes and flexibility is essential.

review_title: Honestly, a great place to work!
job_title: Assistant Store Manager in Burbank, CA
pros: promotions, money is okay if you're young and don't have a lot of responsibilities.
cons: culture, it really depends on the district you're with and there are way way too many gray areas when it comes to management, favoritism etc.

pros: Great company to work for over all. Really depends on what department you are in. Working in the phone bank stinks and is really hard to move up or out of that position. Benefits are ok.
cons: Customer service should be just that....not sell, sell, sell. Main reason I am looking for a new job. Way too much focus on sales and referals instead of just servicing the call. QA is way too strict and picky.

review_title: Wells Fargo Was Very Up front about the fact that they do not care about their Commissioned Mortgage Consultants
job_title: Home Mortgage Consultant in Everett, WA
pros: They pay well based on the fact that ~50% of your business comes from their existing customers.  Where else can Branch Managers and Mid-Level Managers make over $300,000 annually.  No other industry that I know of.
cons: Incompetent Mid-Level Management. No true commitment to customer service or caring about customers.  They act like they care in the media and ads, but behind closed doors, it's all about dollars.

job_title: Loan Administration Manager in Oakland, CA
pros: Very good compensation levels for senior managers, significant incentives available for strong performance.  Talented leadership team with lots of resources (data, systems, etc.) available to assist in running the business.
cons: Senior level management positions are located in key cities so promotional opportunities without relocation may be limited.  However, this is not necessarily unique to Wells.  Promotion opportunities in some departments may be limited due to the tenure of managers and little growth that is occurring in the business at this time.

review_title: Credit Analyst / Underwriter, Private Wealth Management
pros: The company treated me well with annual salary adjustments in line with my performance.  The employee benefit programs were generous and saved me a considerable amount of money.
cons: There was not enough encouragement to move up in the company, with little training other than just for the position held.

pros: They provide a great deal of training and initial support. They have programs that help first time mortgage bankers get a good start.
cons: They have one of the lowest commission structures in the business. The nature of the business itself is subject to market fluctuations that can claim a newbie early.

review_title: This has been a great company to work for. Management truly cares about the employees.
pros: A big pro is the people you work for and with. They promote a friendly atmosphere. Management is committed to help you reach your goals, even if it isn't with your current like if business.
cons: As with many companies today, staffing is thin with no real insight as to when that will change. In the meantime, late nights can be expected.

job_title: Senior Vice President in San Francisco, CA
pros: Banker's hours. Undemanding work. Low bar on actual results and achievement.
cons: There's a very specific culture at Wells that values appearance over substance, positivity over reality and ceremony over meaningful work. The performance reviews, required learning courses, objective setting, planning etc. were relentless and pointless. Very little of real impact got done in marketing, mostly executives holding meetings, lots of talk, little action. Things move very slow, uncertainly and ultimately you may find yourself bored and in professional limbo. A very strange culture that can't sustain itself when push eventually comes to shove in the category.

pros: Good company to work for. Great vacation, they really invest in their employees. They encourage you to volunteer at local organizations and will even pay you your salary to do it.
cons: Fairly low pay and high stress. Don't like that they are so sales driven. You can make the customers just as happy when you meet their needs instead of trying to sell them something all the time.

pros: Good hours, valuable experience. Definitely has room to grow and move up within the company. Coworkers are friendly and personable.
cons: Inconsistent management, unrealistic expectations for sales. Bonus structure and base pay is lacking compared to nationwide average. Performance reviews are seldom scheduled and rarely matter in the long run. Seem to be spinning my wheels at times.

pros: I have been with Wells Fargo in a corporate position for over 7 years.  I feel strongly that this is an ethical company that really wants to do the right thing by its customers and employees.  The challenge is that it is huge and there are so many layers and business units.  Just the structure alone makes it very polical and challenging to get things done.
cons: Giant (260,000+ people), bureaucratic, ineffective leaders allowed to stay in position too long.

pros: opportunity to network both internally and externally - freedom to meet clients away from the office
cons: not ever sales counts towards goals - management wants you to shove products down clients throat to make THEIR numbers look good even though it wont help YOUR numbers

review_title: Wells Fargo is a great team

review_title: Not a Place to Start A Career
pros:
This is a sales job. Not a banking job but a sales job. If you go into it knowing this, you won't be disappointed with the work itself. The pay is very generous considering this is a retail sales job. You do not need a business degree (or any college at all) or even any experience in banking . They don't drug test and the background checks aren't the  most through. It's a retail job but one that pays very well.  The benefits are okay. There are better packages out there but again it's a glorified retail sales job so yes it is generous of them to offer health insurance and the PTO is very nice.

Moving up is easy if you do well and make nice with the higher ups.
cons:
There is a reason they throw so much money at bankers when you don't need any banking experience or formal training to get the job.  The turnover is very very high.  People who can get out, usually choose to do so.  Wells Fargo doesn't require any formal education,  they don't conduct drug tests when hiring, and their background checks aren't through.  People who cannot pass these barriers at other places of employment tend to remain instead of moving on from Wells Fargo and so through the years the concentration of people  who are "trapped" grows.
 
Ethics are lacking especially in management. Competition between co-workers is encouraged and often turns sour. Insecurities run very high so it can be pretty cutthroat, if you plan on doing well you better grow thick skin and get used to dealing with passive aggressive attacks. It's a lot like high school and if you go into it realizing this will you'll be better prepared to handle what you see.  It's not a fun place to work and again there's a reason the turn over is so high and just remember there's a reason some people  have to remain there for years despite hating their jobs.

pros: Really progressive company to work for where they encouraged you to take risks and expand your capabilities.  I felt like my career was enhanced by working there.

pros: The bank offers a good benefit package to employees.
cons: Wells Fargo is more concerned with hiring people who are "nice" rather than competent and productive.  This is so they can pay below market compensation.  The bank culture is to hire those with low experience and eventually after many years promote them, versus hiring people with significant experience at all levels and paying them appropriately.  Annual pay raises are typically minimal.  In addition, most managers there are typically people who have no business being in management, and lack the requisite background and skills to adequately manage their staffs.  The bank has a good benefit package, which compensates somewhat for the low pay levels.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Business casual dress throughout the week, amenities on campus were pretty decent, and campus was relatively well kept.

pros: Great Benefits, good hours of operation. PTO available right away where other companies wait a yr to give. Good work/family balance. Company truly cares for community.

job_title: Outbound Sales Specialist in Minneapolis, MN

review_title: Good position for college business majors

review_title: Wells Fargo Centralized Home Mortgage Consultant

pros: They have a nice work hard play hard mentality.  If you work hard you can make decent money and have somewhat of a life.

job_title: Part Time Teller in Corona, CA

job_title: Business Specialist in Broward Highlands, FL

review_title: Great entry level position with ability to advance in the company. Fantastic training.
job_title: Full Time Teller in Seattle, WA

cons: Pressure to push sales (of accounts/ services) lead to shady practices by some... eg. during the end of quarter crunch to meet quotas/ enable promotions/ receive bonuses, I was pressured into opening accounts for myself, and friends/ family. Heard the company was recently sued/ fined for it.

job_title: Senior Vice President Marketing in San Francisco, CA
pros: A company filled with people who have passion who share the love of the coach.  Everyone you interact with seems to have a mission. pros: Wells Fargo is a company that cares about it's employees and are very good at promoting from within.

review_title: Wonderful people to work with, even for a evil corporation.

review_title: I have been working for over 5 years and love working with my customers.

review_title: Down to Earth People; Conservative Culture

pros: Great company and benefits.  Gives you the tools to learn on the job and the ability to progress forward in your career.

review_title: It is a high paying job and a very nice place to work at, the work mates are very kind is is very recommended job
